Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_3.short_title: Helium abundance saturates at 4.19% above 433 km/s
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_3.alt: A column-normalized density map shows helium abundance (vertical axis, 0-10%) versus solar wind speed (horizontal axis, 200-800 km/s).

summary.what_we_see: A column-normalized density map shows helium abundance (vertical axis, 0-10%) versus solar wind speed (horizontal axis, 200-800 km/s). Yellow indicates the most common helium value at each speed; dark purple indicates rare values. A green dashed line traces the mean helium at each speed, bounded by solid green uncertainty lines. A pink dash-dot two-segment fit overlaps the green curve. A vertical cyan line at 433 km/s and a horizontal cyan line at 4.19% mark the saturation point. Below 433 km/s, helium rises steeply from near zero; above it, helium flattens near 4.19%.
summary.the_finding: Helium abundance undergoes a sharp transition at 433 km/s. Below this speed, helium increases steeply with speed from nearly zero, reflecting conditions in magnetically closed source regions where helium struggles to escape the Sun's gravitational pull. Above this speed, helium saturates at 4.19%, indicating wind from magnetically open regions where helium is freely accelerated alongside hydrogen. This saturation speed provides a physically motivated boundary between wind from closed and open magnetic sources, replacing the traditionally arbitrary fast/slow speed threshold.
summary.why_it_matters: Identifying a physically grounded threshold at 433 km/s rather than an arbitrary speed cutoff enables more accurate classification of the solar wind's origin. This saturation speed is measurable with standard plasma instruments aboard most heliophysics spacecraft. It also establishes the baseline against which the paper then examines how wave activity further modifies this boundary, revealing the origin of the Alfvenic slow wind in subsequent figures.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_3.summary_short: Helium abundance undergoes a sharp transition at 433 km/s.
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_3.technical_caption: The helium abundance a function of solar wind speed. A_He has been normalized to its maximum value in each column. The helium abundance monotonically increases from 0% to 4.19% in slow wind and saturates to this A_He = 4.19% in fast solar wind for which v_sw > 433 km s⁻¹.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_4.short_title: Fast wind is exclusively wave-like; slow wind spans all wave levels
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_4.alt: A column-normalized density map shows wave activity (vertical axis, 0-1) versus solar wind speed (horizontal axis, 200-800 km/s).

summary.what_we_see: A column-normalized density map shows wave activity (vertical axis, 0-1) versus solar wind speed (horizontal axis, 200-800 km/s). Yellow marks the most common values at each speed; dark purple and black mark rare values. A cyan curve traces the 60% contour enclosing the most common observations in each speed column. A vertical green band at 433 km/s marks the helium saturation speed. In slow wind below about 380 km/s, observations span all wave activity levels uniformly. Above the saturation speed, the distribution narrows sharply, with nearly all observations concentrated at wave activity above 0.7.
summary.the_finding: Slow solar wind shows no preferred level of wave activity, spanning the full range from 0 to 1, while fast wind is almost exclusively highly wave-like with cross helicity approaching 1. The transition happens near the helium saturation speed of 433 km/s, reinforcing that this speed marks a fundamental change in the dominant source region type. The convergence toward high wave activity in fast wind reflects magnetically open sources where Alfven waves propagate freely, while the spread in slow wind reflects diverse magnetic topologies in closed or intermittently open source regions.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure reveals why wave activity alone cannot classify the solar wind: some slow wind has high wave activity (the Alfvenic slow wind), making it indistinguishable from fast wind by this metric alone. Combining wave activity with helium abundance, as this paper proposes, resolves this ambiguity. The 60% contour intersecting the saturation speed at wave activity of about 0.7 provides a quantitative threshold that later figures use to define the open-field region of the classification plane.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_4.summary_short: Slow solar wind shows no preferred level of wave activity, spanning the full range from 0 to 1, while fast wind is almost exclusively highly wave-like with cross helicity approaching 1.
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_4.technical_caption: The cross helicity as a function of v_sw, normalized to its maximum value in each column. The blue line indicates values at 60% of the maximum in each column. The green line indicates the saturation speed (v_s) as derived in Figure 3.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_5.short_title: Higher wave activity shifts helium saturation to lower speeds
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_5.alt: Fifteen colored lines trace helium abundance versus solar wind speed, colored from dark blue (lowest wave activity) through yellow to dark red (highest wave activity).

summary.what_we_see: Fifteen colored lines trace helium abundance versus solar wind speed, colored from dark blue (lowest wave activity) through yellow to dark red (highest wave activity). Below about 430 km/s, all fifteen lines follow nearly the same steep upward path from zero. Above that speed, they fan apart: blue lines (low wave activity) continue rising while red lines (high wave activity) flatten out. Green data points with error bars mark each line's saturation point. An inset panel zooms into these green points, revealing they form a diagonal trend from lower-right (low wave activity: higher speed, lower abundance) to upper-left (high wave activity: lower speed, higher abundance).
summary.the_finding: The speed at which helium saturates depends systematically on wave activity. In highly wave-like wind, helium reaches its maximum abundance (4.13%) at a lower speed (around 410 km/s). In wind with little wave activity, saturation occurs at a higher speed (around 430 km/s) and lower abundance (3.87%). This anticorrelation means the boundary between open and closed magnetic sources shifts with Alfvenicity. The identical slopes below saturation across all wave levels show that the process depleting helium in closed-field slow wind is independent of Alfven waves.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure provides the key evidence for explaining the Alfvenic slow wind. Because the saturation speed is lower for more wave-like wind, there is a range of speeds (roughly 410-430 km/s) where wind from open magnetic regions overlaps with wind from closed regions. This overlap is the Alfvenic slow wind: it has slow speeds but carries helium abundance and wave activity typical of fast wind from open field regions. The universal slope below saturation constrains theoretical models of helium depletion.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_5.summary_short: The speed at which helium saturates depends systematically on wave activity.
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_5.technical_caption: Fits to A_He(v_sw) in 15 |σ_c| quantiles, which are given by the color bar. The green points are the fit values and uncertainties for the saturation points (v_s, A_s). The insert zooms in on the points.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_6.short_title: Helium depletion below saturation follows one universal curve
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_6.alt: The same fifteen colored lines from Figure 5, now rescaled so each line's saturation point maps to the coordinate (1, 1), marked by a green dot.

summary.what_we_see: The same fifteen colored lines from Figure 5, now rescaled so each line's saturation point maps to the coordinate (1, 1), marked by a green dot. Both axes are dimensionless ratios: speed divided by saturation speed on the horizontal axis, and helium abundance divided by saturation abundance on the vertical axis. Below (1, 1), all fifteen lines collapse onto a single overlapping curve regardless of color. Above (1, 1), the lines separate: dark blue lines (low wave activity) rise steeply while dark red lines (high wave activity) remain nearly flat.
summary.the_finding: Rescaling reveals that helium depletion in slow wind follows a single universal process that is completely independent of wave activity. All fifteen wave-activity groups produce an identical curve below the saturation point, meaning the physics setting helium abundance in closed-field source regions does not involve Alfven waves. Above saturation, wave activity matters: the more wave-like the wind, the flatter the helium trend, consistent with helium being freely accelerated alongside hydrogen in open field regions where waves provide additional acceleration energy.
summary.why_it_matters: The collapse of all curves below saturation into one universal shape provides a strong constraint for theoretical models of slow wind formation. Any viable model must produce helium depletion that does not depend on wave activity. This likely reflects gravitational settling or collisional energy transfer from helium to hydrogen in closed magnetic loops, governed by the loop's thermal structure rather than wave-particle interactions. Above saturation, the wave-dependent behavior constrains open-field acceleration models.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_6.summary_short: Rescaling reveals that helium depletion in slow wind follows a single universal process that is completely independent of wave activity.
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_6.technical_caption: Fits to A_He(v_sw) in 15 |σ_c| quantiles, which are given by the color bar, rescaled to the saturation point (v_s, A_s). The green point indicates (1, 1), the scaled saturation point.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_7.short_title: Saturation speed and abundance anticorrelate with wave activity
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_7.alt: Two vertically stacked panels share a horizontal axis showing wave activity from 0 to 1.

summary.what_we_see: Two vertically stacked panels share a horizontal axis showing wave activity from 0 to 1. In panel (a), fifteen colored dots with error bars show saturation speed (vertical axis, 407-440 km/s). The dots stay near 430 km/s at low wave activity then drop to about 410 km/s at the highest wave activities. A pink dotted line and shaded band at 433 km/s mark the all-data value. Cyan horizontal bands group the points into three distinct levels: 430, 420, and 410 km/s. In panel (b), the dots show saturation abundance (vertical axis, 3.7-4.3%), rising from about 3.87% to 4.13% with increasing wave activity, again grouped by cyan bands at three levels.
summary.the_finding: The saturation speed decreases by 23 km/s (from 433 to 410) while the saturation abundance increases by 0.26 percentage points (from 3.87% to 4.13%) as wave activity increases. Both quantities show three distinct plateaus rather than smooth variation, suggesting step-like transitions between regimes. This anticorrelation means the boundary between open and closed magnetic source regions shifts systematically: more wave-like wind saturates at lower speed but higher helium, directly quantifying how the open/closed transition depends on Alfvenicity.
summary.why_it_matters: The 23 km/s shift in saturation speed between non-Alfvenic and highly Alfvenic wind defines a speed interval (410-433 km/s) where wind classification is ambiguous based on speed alone. This quantitative measurement is the foundation for the paper's proposed classification scheme using helium and wave activity together. The three-plateau structure in both panels may reflect distinct physical regimes in how the solar corona accelerates the wind, constraining future theoretical models.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_8.short_title: Helium density peaks near the closed-to-open source transition
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_8.alt: A logarithmic chart shows hydrogen (solid green line) and helium (orange dash-dot line) particle density versus solar wind speed from 300 to 800 km/s.

summary.what_we_see: A logarithmic chart shows hydrogen (solid green line) and helium (orange dash-dot line) particle density versus solar wind speed from 300 to 800 km/s. Semitransparent bands show standard deviations. Hydrogen decreases monotonically from about 10 to 2.6 particles per cubic centimeter. Helium rises from about 0.12 to a peak of 0.2 near 409-415 km/s, then decreases to about 0.12 at the fastest speeds. Color-coded segments highlight key speed ranges on the helium line: purple for the slow and fast wind peaks (v_slow, v_fast), orange for the helium density peak (v_n), cyan for the saturation speed range (v_s), and gray for the Gaussian intersection speed (v_i).
summary.the_finding: While hydrogen density simply decreases with speed, helium density reaches a distinct peak at 409 km/s, right where the transition between closed and open magnetic source regions occurs. This peak falls within the range of saturation speeds derived across wave-activity quantiles. The close clustering of v_slow, v_n, v_s, and v_i within a narrow speed interval (355-484 km/s) indicates that multiple physical transitions overlap in this range, suggesting the traditional fast/slow boundary is not a single threshold but a complex transition zone.
summary.why_it_matters: The helium density peak provides independent confirmation of the source-region transition identified by the saturation analysis. It suggests that maximum helium loading into the solar wind occurs precisely where closed-field sources give way to open-field sources. Above this speed, helium density falls along with hydrogen, consistent with helium acting as a simple additional mass term in open-field wind. This constrains models of how the Sun's corona partitions energy between hydrogen and helium during solar wind acceleration.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_9.short_title: Five characteristic speeds span the fast/slow transition zone
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_9.alt: The solar minimum speed distribution from Figure 1 is shown as a solid black curve on a logarithmic vertical axis.

summary.what_we_see: The solar minimum speed distribution from Figure 1 is shown as a solid black curve on a logarithmic vertical axis. Five color-coded segments highlight consecutive speed ranges: v_slow in purple near 355 km/s at the distribution peak, v_n in orange near 409 km/s just below the peak's shoulder, v_s in cyan spanning 407-439 km/s along the declining slope, v_i in green near 484 km/s farther down the slope, and v_fast in purple near 622 km/s at the fast-wind shoulder. The highlighted segments trace sequentially from the slow-wind peak down toward the fast-wind shoulder.
summary.the_finding: The five characteristic speeds derived throughout this paper map onto consecutive portions of the solar minimum speed distribution. They reveal that the broad transition zone between the slow and fast wind peaks (approximately 355-484 km/s) contains multiple distinct physical transitions occurring in sequence: first the slow wind peak, then peak helium loading, then helium saturation, then the equal mixing point of slow and fast source populations. The transition region spans roughly 130 km/s rather than occurring at a single boundary.
summary.why_it_matters: By placing all derived speeds onto the observed distribution, this figure explains why the fast/slow boundary has been so difficult to define: it is not a single boundary but a sequence of overlapping transitions. Different studies have chosen different thresholds because different physical signatures change at slightly different speeds within this zone. The paper's proposed classification using helium and wave activity avoids this ambiguity entirely by not relying on a single speed threshold to separate source regions.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_10a.short_title: Mean speed in the helium-wave plane reveals two source populations

Cool blue-green colors indicate slow wind; warm orange-red colors indicate fast wind. Pink dash-dot contour pairs labeled 355 and 399 km/s mark the slow wind peak range. summary.why_it_matters: This panel demonstrates the paper's central practical result: combining helium abundance and wave activity creates a classification space that separates solar wind sources more effectively than speed. The contour structure reveals why a single speed threshold fails -- at any speed in the transition zone (407-484 km/s), wind from both open and closed sources is present. Critically, this classification requires only standard plasma instruments, not a mass spectrometer, making it applicable to nearly all heliophysics missions.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_10b.short_title: The slowest 10% of wind stays below 390 km/s everywhere

summary.what_we_see: The same axes as panel (a) -- wave activity versus helium abundance -- now colored by the 10th percentile of speed (color scale 270-690 km/s). summary.the_finding: Even in regions of the helium-wave activity plane most definitively associated with magnetically open sources, the slowest 10% of observations have speeds characteristic of traditional slow wind (360-390 km/s). This means that at any point in this classification space, some observations will have speeds that would be misclassified under a simple speed threshold. The near-uniform 10th percentile across the plane demonstrates that speed alone is a poor discriminator of source region type at the level of individual observations.
summary.why_it_matters: This panel provides direct evidence that speed-based classification fails at the individual-observation level. One in ten measurements in the most definitively open-field region still has speeds below 390 km/s. Using helium and wave activity to classify source regions avoids this problem because these properties are set at different heights in the Sun's atmosphere, independently of the speed changes that occur during the wind's transit from the Sun to Earth through interplanetary space.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_11.short_title: A new classification maps solar wind to its magnetic source
Alterman_2025_ApJL_982_L40/fig_11.alt: A cartoon diagram divides the wave activity (horizontal axis, 0-1) versus helium abundance (vertical axis, 0-10%) plane into four labeled regions using black contour boundaries.

summary.what_we_see: A cartoon diagram divides the wave activity (horizontal axis, 0-1) versus helium abundance (vertical axis, 0-10%) plane into four labeled regions using black contour boundaries. A large green region labeled 'Closed Field' fills the bottom of the plane up to about 4.2% helium. A red region labeled 'Open Field' occupies the right edge at high wave activity. A yellow-orange region labeled 'Mixed Source' fills the middle. A small red region labeled 'Transients' sits in the upper left corner. A gray band across the lower boundary of the Mixed region marks the full range of saturation speeds. A curved arrow labeled 'More Open' in the Mixed region points toward the Open Field boundary.
summary.the_finding: This classification scheme distills the quantitative contour analysis into a practical map of solar wind source regions. Wind with low helium (below about 4.2%) at any wave activity likely originates from magnetically closed regions like helmet streamers. Wind with high wave activity (above 0.73) and moderate helium likely comes from magnetically open regions like coronal holes. The broad middle region represents mixed observations where both source types contribute. Within the mixed region, higher wave activity increases the likelihood of an open field origin, as indicated by the arrow.
summary.why_it_matters: This classification scheme is the central practical result of the paper. It identifies solar wind source regions using only helium abundance and cross helicity, without requiring a mass spectrometer for elemental or charge-state composition. Most heliophysics spacecraft carry plasma instruments capable of these measurements, making this scheme widely applicable. It directly addresses the first of nine outstanding questions in solar wind physics identified by Viall and Borovsky: from where on the Sun does the solar wind originate?

Alterman_2025_ApJL_984_L64/fig_1.short_title: Alfven wave forcing explains the fastest solar wind at Earth
Alterman_2025_ApJL_984_L64/fig_1.alt: A smooth black curve on a logarithmic vertical axis plots how frequently the solar wind arrives at Earth at each speed, from about 270 to 750 kilometers per second.

summary.what_we_see: A smooth black curve on a logarithmic vertical axis plots how frequently the solar wind arrives at Earth at each speed, from about 270 to 750 kilometers per second. The distribution rises sharply to a tall peak near 355 km/s (slow wind), then descends through an intermediate range before forming a lower, broader shoulder around 622 km/s (fast wind). Colored bands overlay the curve, each marking a characteristic speed range: cyan highlights the slow and fast wind peaks, magenta marks the transition zone where source regions shift, green spans the speeds predicted by a solar wind model with and without wave-driven acceleration, and orange marks speeds predicted from near-Sun energy measurements by Parker Solar Probe.
summary.the_finding: The speed ranges predicted independently from near-Sun energy measurements (v_K = 557-700 km/s, orange) and from a solar wind model that includes Alfven wave forcing (v_IPW = 620-671 km/s, green) both land on the observed fast wind peak. Removing wave forcing from the same model drops the predicted speeds to 434-554 km/s (v_IP, green), which falls squarely in the intermediate zone between the slow and fast peaks. The difference demonstrates that Alfven waves — magnetic oscillations that propagate along the solar wind's magnetic field — continuously deposit energy during transit and are responsible for boosting solar wind from intermediate speeds up to the 600+ km/s range observed at Earth.
summary.why_it_matters: By synthesizing observations from three vantage points — Wind near Earth, Parker Solar Probe near the Sun, and Solar Orbiter in between — this figure unifies the picture of how the solar wind reaches its observed speeds. It shows that speed alone cannot reliably trace the wind back to its origin on the Sun because wave acceleration in transit reshapes the speed distribution. Instead, Alfvenicity, the degree of wave activity carried by the solar wind, serves as a more faithful fingerprint of the source region's magnetic topology. This distinction matters for space weather forecasting, where correctly identifying the source determines the expected particle and magnetic field conditions at Earth.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_984_L64/fig_2.short_title: Near-Sun energy predicts near-Earth fast wind speeds
Alterman_2025_ApJL_984_L64/fig_2.alt: A two-dimensional heatmap plots kinetic energy flux (vertical axis, 0 to 1.4 milliwatts per square meter) against solar wind speed (horizontal axis, about 300 to 800 km/s).

summary.what_we_see: A two-dimensional heatmap plots kinetic energy flux (vertical axis, 0 to 1.4 milliwatts per square meter) against solar wind speed (horizontal axis, about 300 to 800 km/s). The color scale runs from deep purple (few observations) through lavender to white (most common value at each speed); each column is independently normalized so the most frequent energy value appears white regardless of how often that speed occurs. A black dash-dotted line traces the peak energy flux at each speed, flanked by solid black lines marking the spread. A thick black segment on the central trend highlights the fast wind speed range. A horizontal orange band at approximately 0.62-0.66 mW/m^2 stretches across the full width, marking the kinetic energy flux predicted from near-Sun Parker Solar Probe measurements.
summary.the_finding: Kinetic energy flux increases steadily with solar wind speed, and the horizontal orange band — derived from scaling near-Sun Parker Solar Probe energy measurements outward using empirically determined power laws — intersects the observed trend at speeds of 557-700 km/s. This intersection falls precisely on the fast wind peak. The match demonstrates that the energy budget measured close to the Sun is sufficient to account for the kinetic energy carried by the fastest nontransient solar wind observed at Earth, without requiring any additional unaccounted energy source. Above 740 km/s the data become too sparse during the declining phase of solar activity for reliable fitting, but the key intersection occurs well below that threshold.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure bridges the observational gap between the inner heliosphere and Earth's orbit. Parker Solar Probe measures the solar wind's energy near the Sun, but the scientific question is whether that energy can explain conditions at Earth. By demonstrating that the predicted and observed kinetic energy fluxes converge at fast wind speeds, this analysis validates the use of inner-heliosphere measurements for predicting near-Earth solar wind properties — a key step toward improving space weather forecasting that relies on connecting remote and in situ observations across very different distances from the Sun.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_984_L64/fig_3.short_title: Log-normal fit captures the skewed energy distribution at each speed
Alterman_2025_ApJL_984_L64/fig_3.alt: A single panel shows the distribution of kinetic energy flux values measured for solar wind arriving between 620 and 630 km/s, near the center of the fast wind peak.

summary.what_we_see: A single panel shows the distribution of kinetic energy flux values measured for solar wind arriving between 620 and 630 km/s, near the center of the fast wind peak. The horizontal axis spans 0 to 1.5 milliwatts per square meter; the vertical axis shows the normalized count from 0 to 1. Black open-square markers connected by thin lines trace the observed data, which rises steeply from zero, peaks near 0.5 mW/m^2, and then falls off more gradually toward higher fluxes, with a secondary hump near 1.0 mW/m^2. An orange dash-dotted curve shows the best-fit log-normal function, whose equation and three fit parameters (m, s, A) are displayed in a tan box at upper right.
summary.the_finding: The kinetic energy flux at a given solar wind speed does not follow a symmetric bell curve. Instead, it follows a log-normal distribution with a pronounced rightward tail toward higher energy values. This asymmetry means the most common flux value is lower than the average, and occasional high-energy parcels carry substantially more kinetic energy than typical. The log-normal shape arises naturally when energy is added through a series of multiplicative processes during transit, consistent with repeated Alfven wave energy deposition as the solar wind propagates from the Sun to Earth. This fitting procedure, applied at each 10 km/s speed bin, generates the central trend line in Figure 2.
summary.why_it_matters: Characterizing the statistical shape of the energy distribution — rather than just its average — reveals the physical process driving solar wind acceleration. A log-normal distribution points to multiplicative energy gains, which is the expected signature of wave-driven acceleration where successive wave packets each add a fractional energy boost. For space weather applications, knowing the distribution shape helps forecast the probability of extreme kinetic energy flux events that could drive stronger-than-expected geomagnetic disturbances and affect satellites, power grids, and astronaut safety.

Alterman_2025_ApJL_984_L64/fig_4.short_title: Two Gaussians separate slow and fast wind populations
Alterman_2025_ApJL_984_L64/fig_4.alt: A logarithmic-scale plot shows the observed solar wind speed distribution as a thin black line spanning roughly 270 to 750 km/s, with a prominent peak near 355 km/s and a lower shoulder near 622 km/s.

summary.what_we_see: A logarithmic-scale plot shows the observed solar wind speed distribution as a thin black line spanning roughly 270 to 750 km/s, with a prominent peak near 355 km/s and a lower shoulder near 622 km/s. Thick green segments overlay the black curve at speeds below 400 km/s and above 600 km/s, marking the data subsets used for fitting. An orange dashed Gaussian is fit to the slow wind peak, and an orange dash-dotted Gaussian is fit to the fast wind peak. Both Gaussians extend across the full speed range, visually revealing where they cross. A gray shaded vertical band near 450-520 km/s highlights v_i, the range of speeds where the two Gaussians intersect and the slow and fast wind contribute equally.
summary.the_finding: The bimodal solar wind speed distribution during the declining phase of solar activity cleanly decomposes into two overlapping Gaussian populations. The slow wind peak is five times taller and narrower (center 355 km/s, width 44 km/s), reflecting the dominance of slow wind in near-Earth observations. The fast wind peak is broader (center 622 km/s, width 58 km/s) but clearly distinct. Their intersection at v_i = 484 ± 34 km/s defines the crossover speed where intermittently open and continuously open source regions contribute equally to the near-Earth solar wind, establishing a quantitative boundary between the two populations.
summary.why_it_matters: This Gaussian decomposition provides the quantitative foundation for the entire analysis. The characteristic speeds derived here — v_slow = 355 km/s, v_fast = 622 km/s, v_i = 484 km/s — serve as the benchmarks against which near-Sun energy predictions and wave-acceleration models are compared in the main figures. By performing this decomposition during the declining phase of solar activity, when the Sun's polar and equatorial magnetic structures are cleanly separated, the analysis isolates the two source populations under the most favorable observational conditions and establishes baseline speeds for comparison with theoretical models.

Slow wind Gaussian: center μ_slow = 355 ± 1 km/s, width σ_slow = 44 ± 2 km/s, amplitude A_slow = (5.9 ± 0.1) × 10^-3 (Table 1). Fast wind Gaussian: center μ_fast = 622 ± 2 km/s, width σ_fast = 58 ± 2 km/s, amplitude A_fast = (1.05 ± 0.01) × 10^-3 (Table 1). Supplemental figure demonstrating decomposition method and quantifying characteristic speeds for slow and fast wind populations.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_1.short_title: Helium abundance rises with speed then saturates
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_1.alt: This heatmap shows how frequently the solar wind contains different amounts of helium (vertical axis) at each speed (horizontal axis), with brighter warm colors indicating more common combinations.

summary.what_we_see: This heatmap shows how frequently the solar wind contains different amounts of helium (vertical axis) at each speed (horizontal axis), with brighter warm colors indicating more common combinations. A blue line traces the average helium at each speed, and a dashed green line shows a two-segment fit. At low speeds, helium rises steeply from near zero. Above about 430 km/s, the average helium levels off at roughly 4.2 percent, forming a plateau the authors call saturation. Each column is normalized to its own maximum so that the less frequently observed fast wind remains visible.
summary.the_finding: The helium content of the solar wind follows a simple two-part pattern: it increases linearly with speed in slow wind, then abruptly flattens at a saturation point of 433 km/s and 4.19 percent helium. This saturation abundance equals about half the Sun's photospheric helium. The transition statistically marks where the dominant source of solar wind shifts from regions on the Sun that open and close intermittently to regions that remain continuously open to space.
summary.why_it_matters: This saturation pattern is the foundation for the entire paper. The authors will show that what appears to be a simple plateau actually contains hidden structure when hydrogen density fluctuations are accounted for. Understanding what controls helium content helps identify where on the Sun a given parcel of wind originated, which is critical for predicting the space weather conditions that affect satellites, power grids, and astronaut safety.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_1.summary_short: The helium content of the solar wind follows a simple two-part pattern: it increases linearly with speed in slow wind, then abruptly flattens at a saturation point of 433 km/s and 4.19 percent helium.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_1.technical_caption: The helium abundance as a function of solar wind speed. A_He has been normalized to its maximum value in each column. The blue line indicates the mean value of A_He in each column. The dashed–dotted green line is a bilinear fit to these means using Equation (2). The helium abundance monotonically increases from 0% to 4.19% in slow wind and saturates to this A_He = 4.19% in fast solar wind for which v_sw > 433 km s^-1.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_2.short_title: Alfvenic wave activity concentrates in faster wind
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_2.alt: This contour plot shows how the normalized cross helicity, a measure of Alfvenic wave activity (vertical axis), varies with solar wind speed (horizontal axis).

summary.what_we_see: This contour plot shows how the normalized cross helicity, a measure of Alfvenic wave activity (vertical axis), varies with solar wind speed (horizontal axis). Brighter contour levels indicate more common combinations. A black contour at the 0.7 level marks a reference boundary. At slow speeds, wave activity spans a wide range of values centered around 0.5. As speed increases, the distribution narrows and shifts upward toward 1.0, meaning faster wind is increasingly dominated by Alfvenic magnetic wave oscillations.
summary.the_finding: The solar wind becomes increasingly Alfvenic as speed rises. Wind with cross helicity above 0.7 predominantly originates from regions of the Sun that are continuously open to space, while lower cross helicity indicates more complex or mixed origins. This baseline trend sets up the paper's key question: if fast wind should be wave-rich, why does some fast wind carry unexpectedly low wave activity and anomalous helium levels?
summary.why_it_matters: This figure establishes the baseline relationship between wave activity and speed that underpins the entire analysis. By showing that faster wind is typically more Alfvenic, it provides context for the central puzzle: compressive density fluctuations that the cross helicity alone cannot capture turn out to explain why some fast wind deviates from this expected trend. Understanding these deviations matters for correctly identifying where the solar wind originates on the Sun.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_2.summary_short: The solar wind becomes increasingly Alfvenic as speed rises.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_2.technical_caption: A contour plot of the pdf of |σ_c|. The columns in the underlying 2D histogram have been normalized to their maximum value. The contour at 0.7 is indicated in black.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_3.short_title: Three-parameter map classifies solar wind by origin
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_3.alt: This schematic diagram divides the solar wind into regions based on wave activity (horizontal axis) and helium content (vertical axis), with speed shown by contour lines.

summary.what_we_see: This schematic diagram divides the solar wind into regions based on wave activity (horizontal axis) and helium content (vertical axis), with speed shown by contour lines. A green region at the bottom marks wind from intermittently open sources. A red region at upper right marks wind from continuously open sources. An orange region in the middle represents wind of ambiguous origin. A small red region at upper left highlights helium-rich but wave-poor wind that the companion paper hypothesizes comes from transient events. An arrow labeled 'More Open' points toward the continuously open region.
summary.the_finding: By combining wave activity, helium content, and speed, the solar wind can be statistically classified by its origin on the Sun. Low-helium wind comes from intermittently open sources regardless of wave activity. Highly wave-active wind with above-saturation helium comes from continuously open sources. A large intermediate region exists where the source is ambiguous, and the upper left corner with high helium but low wave activity was left unexplained by the companion paper.
summary.why_it_matters: This classification diagram from the companion paper is the starting point for the central question addressed here: what causes helium-rich, wave-poor solar wind? This paper demonstrates that hydrogen compressibility resolves the ambiguity, distinguishing genuinely open-source wind from compressively enhanced wind that masquerades as fast wind. Resolving this ambiguity is essential for accurate space weather source region identification.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_3.summary_short: By combining wave activity, helium content, and speed, the solar wind can be statistically classified by its origin on the Sun.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_3.technical_caption: A plot of v_sw as a function of |σ_c| and A_He with contours at v_sw = 300 and 460 km s^-1. Paper I considers helium-poor solar wind with A_He < A_s to originate in intermittently open source regions and Alfvénic solar wind with |σ_c| > 0.7 in the red region to originate in continuously open source regions. That work hypothesizes that the speed enhancement of non-Alfvénic, helium-rich solar wind in the upper left corner of the plot is due to transients.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_4.short_title: Hydrogen density fluctuations persist across all speeds
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_4.alt: This contour plot shows how much the hydrogen density fluctuates (vertical axis, logarithmic scale) at each solar wind speed (horizontal axis).

summary.what_we_see: This contour plot shows how much the hydrogen density fluctuates (vertical axis, logarithmic scale) at each solar wind speed (horizontal axis). Brighter regions indicate more common combinations. At slow speeds, the fluctuations cluster around moderate values near 0.05 to 0.1. As speed increases past about 400 km/s, the most common fluctuation level decreases into the incompressible regime below 0.05, but a tail of large fluctuations extends upward at all speeds, including the fastest.
summary.the_finding: Hydrogen compressibility changes systematically with solar wind speed. Slow wind shows a relatively narrow range of moderate compressibility. Fast wind is typically less compressible, consistent with wave-dominated wind where density stays relatively steady. However, a population of highly compressive fast wind persists, creating an asymmetric tail. These compressive fluctuations above 0.1 are present across all speeds, which is the key to explaining helium anomalies in fast wind.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure introduces the paper's central innovation: hydrogen compressibility as a third classification variable. While previous work classified solar wind using speed and wave activity, this paper shows that density fluctuations carry independent information about the wind's origin. The coexistence of compressive and incompressible fast wind at the same speed is the first hint that speed alone cannot distinguish different types of fast solar wind.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_4.summary_short: Hydrogen compressibility changes systematically with solar wind speed.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_4.technical_caption: A contour plot of the pdf of |δn_H/n_H|(v_sw). In the underlying 2D histogram, the frequency of observing |δn_H/n_H| in each column is normalized to its maximum value. The contours are smoothed with a 1σ Gaussian kernel for visual clarity.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_5.short_title: Compressibility and wave activity are inversely related
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_5.alt: This contour plot maps the average hydrogen density fluctuation level using color across solar wind speed (horizontal axis) and wave activity (vertical axis).

summary.what_we_see: This contour plot maps the average hydrogen density fluctuation level using color across solar wind speed (horizontal axis) and wave activity (vertical axis). Cooler blues indicate low compressibility where density stays steady, while warmer yellows and oranges indicate high compressibility. A purple curve from a previous figure marks the 0.7 wave activity contour. A black contour at 0.1 separates compressive from incompressible regimes. Below the purple boundary, compressibility is generally high. Above it, compressibility is low, especially at high speeds.
summary.the_finding: Compressibility and wave activity are inversely related across the speed-wave activity plane. The most compressible solar wind has low wave activity regardless of speed, while the most incompressible wind has high wave activity. The purple 0.7 contour from the wave activity distribution closely tracks the boundary between compressible and incompressible regions. This anticorrelation is most prominent at high speeds and virtually absent at low speeds, because compressible and incompressible wind overlap in the same speed range at lower speeds.
summary.why_it_matters: By mapping compressibility onto the speed-wave activity plane, this figure demonstrates that compressibility provides independent information beyond what wave activity alone reveals. The distinct spatial patterns enable the authors to separate solar wind genuinely from open magnetic sources (incompressible, wave-rich) from wind carrying compressive fluctuations of potentially different origin. This sets up the quantitative analysis that follows.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_5.summary_short: Compressibility and wave activity are inversely related across the speed-wave activity plane.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_5.technical_caption: A contour plot of the pdf of |δn_H/n_H|(v_sw, |σ_c|). Average |δn_H/n_H| is calculated as the logarithmic mean. Contours are smoothed with a 1σ Gaussian kernel for visual clarity. The purple line is the 0.7 contour from Figure 2.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_6.short_title: Wave activity maps onto the helium-speed plane
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_6.alt: This contour plot shows the average wave activity level (color) as a function of solar wind speed (horizontal axis) and helium abundance (vertical axis).

summary.what_we_see: This contour plot shows the average wave activity level (color) as a function of solar wind speed (horizontal axis) and helium abundance (vertical axis). Warm reds indicate high wave activity; cool blues indicate low. Black points mark saturation points for different wave activity levels, all falling above the 0.6 contour highlighted in black. A shaded region bounded by colored dashed lines shows the envelope of helium-speed fits across wave activity quantiles, and solid black lines bound a narrow 530 to 560 km/s crossover speed range.
summary.the_finding: The saturation points consistently fall in the region of moderately high wave activity, above the 0.6 contour. The envelope of helium-speed fits spans a narrow speed range of 530 to 560 km/s where fits at low and high wave activity cross over. This crossover is the speed at which non-Alfvenic wind begins to carry more helium than wave-dominated wind at the same speed. This creates an apparent paradox: wind from supposedly intermittent sources carrying more helium than wind from open sources.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure connects the paper's three key variables in a single view. By showing that saturation points cluster in wave-rich territory and that low-wave-activity fits eventually exceed high-wave-activity fits, it demonstrates that something beyond wave activity determines helium behavior at high speeds. That something, the paper argues, is hydrogen compressibility. Resolving this paradox is the central goal of the subsequent analysis.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_6.summary_short: The saturation points consistently fall in the region of moderately high wave activity, above the 0.6 contour.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_6.technical_caption: A contour plot of the normalized cross helicity as a function of solar wind speed and helium abundance. The contours are smoothed with a 1σ Gaussian filter for clarity. The contour at |σc| = 0.6 is highlighted in black. The black points mark the saturation point (vs, As). The saturation points occur at |σc| > 0.6. The shaded black region corresponds to fits to AHe(vsw) for each |σc| quantile: the red dashed–dotted line is the high-|σc| edge, and the blue dashed–dotted line is the low-|σc| edge. The region from 530 to 560 km s⁻¹ is where the maximum and minimum |σc| fits to AHe(|σc|) cross. This region is bounded by solid black lines and crosses the |σc| = 0.7 contour.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_7.short_title: Compressibility reveals structure hidden in the helium plateau
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_7.alt: This contour plot shows the average hydrogen compressibility (color) across solar wind speed (horizontal axis) and helium abundance (vertical axis).

summary.what_we_see: This contour plot shows the average hydrogen compressibility (color) across solar wind speed (horizontal axis) and helium abundance (vertical axis). Blue regions indicate low compressibility and warmer regions indicate higher compressibility. The same saturation envelope from the previous figure is overlaid. A box near the saturation points marks the region enlarged in the next figure. Black curves from the companion study trace the mean and one-sigma spread of the overall helium-speed relationship.
summary.the_finding: The compressibility contours reveal a gradient that shifts direction across the saturation points. Below saturation, compressibility is relatively uniform. Above saturation, wind with helium above the typical value has distinctly higher compressibility than wind at the saturation level. This gradient is steepest near the crossover region at 530 to 560 km/s, precisely where the companion paper's helium paradox appears. The most common helium-speed combinations fall within the incompressible region where compressibility stays below 0.09.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure provides the first visual evidence for the paper's central claim: the unexpectedly high helium in some fast wind is associated with compressive fluctuations, not with typical open-source fast wind. The compressibility gradient across the saturation boundary suggests that hydrogen density fluctuations actively regulate how much helium the solar wind carries, connecting composition set deep in the solar atmosphere to fluctuation properties measured at Earth.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_7.summary_short: The compressibility contours reveal a gradient that shifts direction across the saturation points.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_7.technical_caption: A contour plot of the compressibility as a function of solar wind speed and helium abundance. Contours are smoothed with a 1σ Gaussian filter for clarity. Solid black lines are the mean and standard deviations from 1D fits plotted in Paper I, Figure 2. The shaded black region bounded by red and blue dashed–dotted lines matches Figure 6. The region encircled by the box highlights the location of the saturation points (vs, As) and is plotted in Figure 8.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_8.short_title: Compressibility contour gradient reverses at saturation
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_8.alt: This chart zooms into the saturation region from the previous figure, showing compressibility contours near the point where helium stops rising with speed.

summary.what_we_see: This chart zooms into the saturation region from the previous figure, showing compressibility contours near the point where helium stops rising with speed. The contour at the 0.09 level changes slope as it crosses the saturation points marked by black crosses. Solid black lines bound a narrow speed range of 530 to 560 km/s where helium fits at different wave activity levels cross over. This crossover region coincides with the 0.085 compressibility contour, and two separate pockets of compressibility below 0.085 are visible on either side of the saturation zone.
summary.the_finding: At the saturation point, the compressibility contour gradient reverses direction. Below saturation, constant-compressibility contours follow increasing helium and speed together. Above saturation, they tilt so that wind with slightly more helium than the saturation value has noticeably different compressibility. The 0.085 compressibility level emerges as a natural boundary that intersects the crossover region where wave-activity-based fits switch dominance, linking two previously independent threshold values.
summary.why_it_matters: This zoomed view provides detailed evidence that the saturation point corresponds to a real physical transition in the solar wind's density fluctuation behavior, not just a statistical convenience. The gradient reversal connects helium composition, which is set deep in the Sun's atmosphere, to the compressibility of fluctuations that evolve during interplanetary transit, linking two previously independent aspects of solar wind physics.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_8.summary_short: At the saturation point, the compressibility contour gradient reverses direction.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_8.technical_caption: A zoom-in of the region indicated in Figure 7. The gradient of the contour for |δnH/nH| = 0.09 changes across the saturation points. The fits AHe(vsw) cross over the speed range vsw ≈ 530–560 km s⁻¹, which is bounded by solid black lines instead of red and blue dashed–dotted lines. This region where the AHe(vsw) fits at low |σc| become larger than the fits at high |σc| crosses the |δnH/nH| = 0.085 contour.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_9.short_title: Compressible wind drives helium far above the plateau
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_9.alt: Fifteen colored lines trace how helium abundance (vertical axis) changes with solar wind speed (horizontal axis), each representing a different compressibility level from low (dark blue) to high (pink).

summary.what_we_see: Fifteen colored lines trace how helium abundance (vertical axis) changes with solar wind speed (horizontal axis), each representing a different compressibility level from low (dark blue) to high (pink). All lines rise steeply at slow speeds, but they diverge sharply above the saturation point where green markers sit. The incompressible lines (cool colors) flatten into a near-horizontal plateau. The compressible lines (pink, above 0.15) continue rising steeply, reaching helium levels well above the plateau. An inset zooms into the saturation region.
summary.the_finding: When sorted by hydrogen density fluctuation level, two starkly different behaviors emerge above saturation. Incompressible wind with fluctuations below about 15 percent behaves as expected for open-source fast wind: helium reaches a constant plateau. Compressible wind with fluctuations above 15 percent continues accumulating helium with increasing speed, reaching levels well above the plateau. Below saturation, all curves have indistinguishable gradients regardless of compressibility, confirming that the slow-wind helium process is independent of density fluctuations.
summary.why_it_matters: This is the paper's key result figure. It resolves the helium paradox by showing that compressive fluctuations, not a failure of the source-region classification, explain why some fast wind carries more helium than expected. The clean separation between compressible and incompressible behavior reveals hydrogen compressibility as a fundamental regulator of helium abundance in the solar wind.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_9.summary_short: When sorted by hydrogen density fluctuation level, two starkly different behaviors emerge above saturation.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_9.technical_caption: Fits of AHe(vsw) for 15 quantiles of hydrogen compressibility (|δnH/nH|). The color bar identifies |δnH/nH|. Quantiles with |δnH/nH| > 0.15 are indicated in pink. The green plots indicate the saturation points (vs, As).

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_10.short_title: Incompressible curves collapse onto a universal shape
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_10.alt: The same fifteen helium-speed curves from the previous figure are rescaled so that each saturation point sits at coordinates (1, 1).

summary.what_we_see: The same fifteen helium-speed curves from the previous figure are rescaled so that each saturation point sits at coordinates (1, 1). Below saturation (left of the green marker), all curves nearly overlap, forming a tight bundle regardless of compressibility level. Above saturation (right of the green marker), the incompressible curves remain tightly bundled near a flat line at 1.0, while the compressible curves (pink) splay upward, diverging sharply from the universal pattern.
summary.the_finding: When each curve is normalized to its own saturation point, the incompressible curves collapse onto a single universal shape. The helium-speed relationship below saturation follows the same functional form regardless of compressibility, with only the saturation point shifting. Above saturation, universal behavior breaks only for compressible wind. This collapse confirms that a single physical process governs helium in incompressible wind, while compressive fluctuations introduce a separate, additional process that drives helium above saturation.
summary.why_it_matters: Universal scaling in physics signals underlying simplicity in the governing process. The collapse of incompressible curves suggests that helium abundance in non-compressive solar wind is controlled by a single mechanism depending only on the saturation parameters. This simplification could enable more accurate models of helium distribution in the solar wind, improving predictions of chemical composition near Earth.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_10.summary_short: When each curve is normalized to its own saturation point, the incompressible curves collapse onto a single universal shape.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_10.technical_caption: Fits to AHe(vsw) in 15 |δnH/nH| quantiles. Each fit is scaled to its saturation point (vs, As), which is indicated at (1, 1) in green. As in Figure 9, the quantiles are indicated by the color bar.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_11.short_title: Saturation speed and abundance shift at the compressibility boundary
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_11.alt: Two panels show how the saturation point changes with hydrogen compressibility (horizontal axis).

summary.what_we_see: Two panels show how the saturation point changes with hydrogen compressibility (horizontal axis). Panel (a) shows saturation speed: approximately constant near 428 km/s for incompressible quantiles (circles, compressibility below 0.15), then stepping up markedly for compressible quantiles (pink squares) to a maximum of 502 km/s. Panel (b) shows saturation helium abundance: roughly constant near 4.2 percent for incompressible quantiles, but non-monotonic in the compressible subset, dropping to 3.9 percent before rising to 4.13 percent at the highest compressibility. Cyan bands mark wave-activity intervals from the companion paper.
summary.the_finding: Saturation speed increases with compressibility, stepping up sharply at the incompressible-compressible boundary near 0.15. Saturation helium abundance is approximately constant in incompressible wind but non-monotonic in compressible wind, first decreasing to a local minimum before rising at the highest compressibility. The 0.085 compressibility level (blue-edged marker) emerges as a transition between regimes, mirroring the pattern found across wave activity levels in the companion paper.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure quantifies how the slow-to-fast wind transition depends on compressibility and provides the numerical foundation for mapping between the companion paper's wave-activity results and this paper's compressibility results. The systematic shift of the saturation point challenges the traditional view of a single dividing speed between slow and fast solar wind and suggests the transition depends on fluctuation properties.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_11.summary_short: Saturation speed increases with compressibility, stepping up sharply at the incompressible-compressible boundary near 0.15.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_11.technical_caption: The saturation point (v_s, A_s) as a function of |δn_H/n_H|. Points are connected by a dotted line to aid the eye. Uncertainties are plotted as error bars with the same color as the markers, and a semitransparent gray envelope traces out the envelope surrounding the error bars. Markers are colored by |δn_H/n_H| to facilitate comparison with other figures. As above, quantiles with |δn_H/n_H| > 0.15 are shown with pink squares. The edge of the marker corresponding to the quantile for which |δn_H/n_H| = 0.085 is blue. The blue horizontal regions correspond to average values of (a) v_s and (b) A_He for key ranges of |σ_c| derived in Paper I.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_12.short_title: Compressive wind has six times steeper helium gradients
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_12.alt: This scatter plot shows the slope of the helium-speed relationship above saturation (vertical axis) versus hydrogen compressibility (horizontal axis).

summary.what_we_see: This scatter plot shows the slope of the helium-speed relationship above saturation (vertical axis) versus hydrogen compressibility (horizontal axis). Circular markers represent incompressible wind (below 0.15), while pink squares represent compressive wind (above 0.15). Error bars indicate uncertainties. The incompressible points cluster near zero slope at roughly 0.001 percent per km/s. The compressive points jump dramatically to slopes five to six times larger, with the steepest value of about 0.006 at the highest compressibility.
summary.the_finding: The helium gradient above saturation is nearly zero for incompressible wind, consistent with the expected flat plateau from open-source fast wind, but increases sharply for compressive wind. The transition occurs abruptly near the 0.15 compressibility threshold. This confirms that the large helium gradients identified in the companion paper's low-wave-activity analysis were driven specifically by compressive fluctuations rather than by low wave activity itself.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure provides the clearest quantitative evidence that compressible fluctuations cause anomalous helium behavior in fast wind. The sharp transition at 0.15 defines a practical threshold for separating two physically distinct solar wind populations, directly applicable in space weather analysis to distinguish genuinely open-source fast wind from compressively enhanced wind that may originate from different solar sources.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_12.summary_short: The helium gradient above saturation is nearly zero for incompressible wind, consistent with the expected flat plateau from open-source fast wind, but increases sharply for compressive wind.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_12.technical_caption: The slopes of A_He(v_sw) for speeds v_sw > v_s in each |δn_H/n_H| quantile. Nominally, this is the slope for the fast solar wind originating in open solar wind regions and we refer to them as "saturation slopes" in this work. Quantiles for which |δn_H/n_H| > 0.15 are plotted in pink and indicated with squares instead of circles. The marker indicating the quantile with |δn_H/n_H| = 0.085 is blue, while all other quantiles have a black marker edge.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_13.short_title: Excluding compressive wind flattens the wave-activity dependence
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_13.alt: Three panels show saturation fit parameters plotted against wave activity, each with multiple colored curves representing different upper limits on allowed compressibility (red for 0.085, green for 0.1, orange for 0.15) plus a purple curve for the compressible subset above 0.15.

summary.what_we_see: Three panels show saturation fit parameters plotted against wave activity, each with multiple colored curves representing different upper limits on allowed compressibility (red for 0.085, green for 0.1, orange for 0.15) plus a purple curve for the compressible subset above 0.15. A blue curve shows all data. Gray horizontal lines mark the overall values ignoring compressibility. Panel (a) shows the saturation slope, panel (b) the saturation speed, and panel (c) the saturation abundance. As compressive wind is progressively excluded, the colored curves converge and flatten.
summary.the_finding: When compressive wind is progressively excluded, the dependence of saturation parameters on wave activity diminishes substantially. All saturation slopes still decrease with increasing wave activity, but excluding compressive wind reduces the slopes and brings incompressible subsets into closer agreement, with the largest reduction at low wave activity. Compressible saturation speed is less than 10 percent larger than incompressible values. Compressible saturation abundance is at most 16 percent smaller. This demonstrates that the companion paper's observation of strongly wave-activity-dependent saturation was substantially driven by the inclusion of compressive fluctuations.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure resolves the central puzzle from the companion paper. What appeared to be a wave-activity effect on helium saturation was actually a compressibility effect correlated with wave activity. This distinction matters for solar wind modeling: helium behavior can be predicted from density fluctuation measurements without needing to first classify the wind by wave activity, simplifying the observational requirements.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_13.summary_short: When compressive wind is progressively excluded, the dependence of saturation parameters on wave activity diminishes substantially.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_13.technical_caption: Saturation fit parameters for different maximum |δn_H/n_H|, given by the legend, as a function of |σ_c| along with the data, irrespective of |δn_H/n_H|. The panels are saturation (a) slope (m_s), (b) speed (v_s), and (c) abundance (A_s). Gray lines are the fit parameters across all observations in Figure 1. The "Comp." subset is compressible solar wind with |δn_H/n_H| > 0.15.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_14.short_title: Derived speeds map onto the bimodal wind distribution
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_14.alt: This chart shows the probability of observing the solar wind at different speeds, forming a tall peak around 355 km/s for slow wind and a smaller shoulder near 622 km/s for fast wind.

summary.what_we_see: This chart shows the probability of observing the solar wind at different speeds, forming a tall peak around 355 km/s for slow wind and a smaller shoulder near 622 km/s for fast wind. Nine color-coded horizontal segments below the curve mark characteristic speed ranges from this paper, the companion paper, and related studies. Each segment is labeled and positioned at different vertical offsets to avoid overlap, creating a visual summary of where different analyses place key transitions in the solar wind.
summary.the_finding: Characteristic speeds from compressibility analysis (this paper), wave activity analysis (companion paper), and independent energy budget studies all map onto distinct, physically meaningful portions of the bimodal speed distribution. The incompressible saturation speed range (417 to 436 km/s) aligns with the transition region between slow and fast wind peaks. The compressible saturation speed range (435 to 508 km/s) falls at higher speeds in the intermediate zone likely corresponding to the Alfvenic slow wind. These speeds collectively delineate where the solar wind's source region character changes.
summary.why_it_matters: By placing all derived speed thresholds on a single distribution, this figure shows how multiple independent analyses converge on a consistent picture of solar wind structure. The speed ranges from density fluctuations complement rather than contradict those from wave activity and energy flux analyses, building confidence that the physical picture is robust. The compressible speed range falling in the intermediate zone where ad hoc slow-fast thresholds are typically set explains longstanding ambiguity in source region identification.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_14.summary_short: Characteristic speeds from compressibility analysis (this paper), wave activity analysis (companion paper), and independent energy budget studies all map onto distinct, physically meaningful portions of the bimodal speed distribution.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15a.short_title: Mean helium reveals two distinct high-helium islands
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15a.alt: This panel maps mean helium abundance (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and hydrogen compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic).

summary.what_we_see: This panel maps mean helium abundance (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and hydrogen compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic). Two separate warm-colored high-helium islands are visible: one at high wave activity with low compressibility (lower right), and another at high compressibility regardless of wave activity (top). A black contour marks the minimum saturation abundance of 3.82 percent. Between these two islands, mean helium is lower and relatively uniform, forming the helium-poor bulk of the solar wind.
summary.the_finding: Enhanced mean helium above saturation exists in two physically separated regions. The Alfvenic island at lower right has high wave activity, low compressibility, and uniformly elevated helium consistent with steady open-source fast wind. The compressive island at top has high compressibility across all wave activity levels and comparable mean helium, but reaches these values through a fundamentally different mechanism. Between the islands, helium stays below the minimum saturation abundance.
summary.why_it_matters: This panel establishes the central visual finding of the paper: two distinct populations of helium-rich solar wind exist in fluctuation parameter space. The mean values alone might suggest these populations are equivalent, but the companion panels revealing the 90th percentile, 10th percentile, and variability will show they differ dramatically in their statistical character, pointing to entirely different physical origins.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15a.summary_short: Enhanced mean helium above saturation exists in two physically separated regions.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15a.technical_caption: Panel (a): Mean helium abundance as a function of cross helicity and solar wind compressibility. The black contours indicate A_He = 3.82% from panel (a), which is the smallest A_s derived in Paper I and this work.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15b.short_title: 90th percentile helium exceeds 7.5% in compressive wind
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15b.alt: This panel maps the 90th percentile of helium abundance (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic).

summary.what_we_see: This panel maps the 90th percentile of helium abundance (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic). The compressive island at top shows the most extreme upper-tail helium values, exceeding 7.5 percent with warm red and orange colors. The Alfvenic island at lower right shows elevated but more moderate upper-tail values that do not exceed about 6 percent. The black contour again marks the 3.82 percent minimum saturation abundance.
summary.the_finding: The upper tail of the helium distribution reaches dramatically higher values in the compressive island (above 7.5 percent) than in the Alfvenic island (below 6 percent). Since helium in standard fast wind from continuously open sources is expected to remain near 50 percent of the photospheric value, these extreme values in the compressive island suggest a fundamentally different enhancement mechanism. The compressive population can push helium to values far exceeding the typical open-source upper bound.
summary.why_it_matters: By showing that the most extreme helium abundances occur exclusively in compressive wind, this panel demonstrates that compressive fluctuations can drive helium to levels inconsistent with steady coronal outflow from open sources. These extreme values are important for understanding ion composition in interplanetary space and have implications for how much helium mass is transported by transient or dynamic events rather than steady-state processes.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15b.summary_short: The upper tail of the helium distribution reaches dramatically higher values in the compressive island (above 7.5 percent) than in the Alfvenic island (below 6 percent).
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15b.technical_caption: Panel (b): 90% quantile of helium abundance as a function of cross helicity and solar wind compressibility.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15c.short_title: 10th percentile helium stays elevated only in Alfvenic wind
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15c.alt: This panel maps the 10th percentile of helium abundance (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic).

summary.what_we_see: This panel maps the 10th percentile of helium abundance (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic). Only the Alfvenic island at lower right shows elevated lower-tail helium, exceeding 1.4 percent in the region with wave activity above about 0.7. The compressive island at top shows low 10th percentile values near or below 1 percent despite having high mean helium. Most of the plane has very low 10th percentile helium, indicating that helium-depleted conditions occur frequently outside the Alfvenic zone.
summary.the_finding: The lower tail of the helium distribution is elevated only in the Alfvenic, incompressible region. Compressive wind has very low 10th percentile helium despite its high mean, meaning compressive helium enhancement is episodic rather than sustained. In contrast, Alfvenic wind maintains elevated helium even at the 10th percentile, indicating a persistently enriched state. This asymmetry between the lower tails of the two islands is what drives the enormous variability difference shown in the next panel.
summary.why_it_matters: The contrast between low floor values in compressive wind and elevated floor values in Alfvenic wind reveals fundamentally different physics. Alfvenic wind from open coronal sources maintains consistently elevated helium, while compressive wind experiences intermittent helium surges interspersed with helium-poor intervals. This distinction is critical for space weather forecasting: compressive helium enhancements cannot be relied upon as steady indicators of source region identity.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15c.summary_short: The lower tail of the helium distribution is elevated only in the Alfvenic, incompressible region.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15c.technical_caption: Panel (c): 10% quantile of helium abundance as a function of cross helicity and solar wind compressibility.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15d.short_title: Helium variability exceeds 70% in the compressive island
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15d.alt: This panel maps the variability of helium abundance (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic).

summary.what_we_see: This panel maps the variability of helium abundance (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic). Variability measures how much the spread between the 90th and 10th percentiles exceeds the mean. The compressive island at top glows with warm colors indicating variability exceeding 70 percent, reaching up to 90 percent in some regions. In contrast, the Alfvenic island at lower right shows cool blues with variability within about 20 percent of the mean. The black contour again marks the 3.82 percent minimum saturation abundance.
summary.the_finding: The two helium-rich populations differ drastically in their variability. Alfvenic wind maintains helium within about 20 percent of its mean, consistent with steady enrichment from continuously open coronal sources. Compressive wind shows 70 to 90 percent variability, meaning the spread between its 10th and 90th percentiles far exceeds the mean itself. Despite comparable mean helium in both islands, the compressive population achieves this through highly intermittent extreme values rather than sustained enrichment.
summary.why_it_matters: This variability contrast is the smoking gun distinguishing the two populations. Steady coronal outflow from open field regions produces consistent helium (low variability), while compressive processes produce episodic helium surges (extreme variability). This panel, together with the three preceding panels, constitutes the paper's most comprehensive visualization, revealing that the traditional binary fast/slow classification misses a third population with unique statistical properties that likely originates from neither standard open nor closed sources.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15d.summary_short: The two helium-rich populations differ drastically in their variability.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_15d.technical_caption: Panel (d): Variability of the helium abundance as a function of cross helicity and solar wind compressibility.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_16a.short_title: Mean speed exceeds saturation only in Alfvenic wind
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_16a.alt: This panel maps mean solar wind speed (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic).

summary.what_we_see: This panel maps mean solar wind speed (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic). Two black contours mark 433 and 450 km/s, the fastest saturation speeds from the companion paper and from incompressible wind in this paper. The fastest mean speeds (warmest colors, above 450 km/s) appear only in the Alfvenic, incompressible region at lower right. The compressive region at top shows moderate mean speeds that do not exceed the saturation speed contours, despite the high helium found there in Figure 15.
summary.the_finding: Mean solar wind speed exceeds the largest incompressible saturation speed only in the Alfvenic, incompressible region. Compressive wind, despite carrying helium comparable to fast wind, has mean speeds that remain below the saturation speed threshold. Contours of constant average speed show an anticorrelation between wave activity and compressibility, meaning the same average speed can be achieved by either Alfvenic or compressive wind through different physical processes.
summary.why_it_matters: This panel demonstrates that speed-based source region classification is fundamentally limited. The compressive population carries fast-wind-like helium but at slower average speeds than the Alfvenic population. Space weather models that rely on speed alone to classify source regions will systematically misidentify compressive wind, which may carry different magnetic field configurations and particle populations than genuine coronal hole wind.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_16a.summary_short: Mean solar wind speed exceeds the largest incompressible saturation speed only in the Alfvenic, incompressible region.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_16a.technical_caption: Panel (a): The solar wind speed as a function of cross helicity and compressibility. The black contour indicates vsw = 433 and 450 km s⁻¹, the fastest vs derived in Paper I and for incompressible solar wind (|δnH/nH| < 0.15) in this work.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_16b.short_title: Speed variability is larger in Alfvenic than compressive wind
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_16b.alt: This panel maps the variability of solar wind speed (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic).

summary.what_we_see: This panel maps the variability of solar wind speed (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and compressibility (vertical axis, logarithmic). The Alfvenic region at lower right shows the highest speed variability with warm colors, while the compressive region at top shows relatively lower speed variability. The black contours at 433 and 450 km/s from panel (a) are also shown. Speed variability is moderate across most of the plane but peaks in the incompressible, high-wave-activity zone.
summary.the_finding: Speed variability is larger in the Alfvenic subset than in the compressive subset, which is the opposite pattern to helium variability in Figure 15d. Compressive wind has highly variable helium but less variable speed, while Alfvenic wind has less variable helium but more variable speed. This decoupling implies that compressibility drives helium changes independently of speed, confirming that compressive density fluctuations rather than speed itself regulate the excess helium in compressive wind.
summary.why_it_matters: The contrast between helium and speed variability patterns across the two populations provides strong evidence that different physical mechanisms control helium in each. If speed were the primary driver of helium enhancement, both quantities should vary together. Their decoupling means that models predicting helium content from speed alone will systematically fail for the compressive population, which constitutes a significant fraction of solar wind at intermediate speeds.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_16b.summary_short: Speed variability is larger in the Alfvenic subset than in the compressive subset, which is the opposite pattern to helium variability in Figure 15d.
