Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_17a.short_title: Mean compressibility concentrates at high helium, low wave activity
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_17a.alt: This panel maps mean hydrogen compressibility (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and helium abundance (vertical axis).

summary.what_we_see: This panel maps mean hydrogen compressibility (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and helium abundance (vertical axis). The highest mean compressibility (warm colors, above 0.15) concentrates at upper left where helium is above about 7 percent and wave activity is below 0.5. The lowest compressibility (cool blues, below 0.085) fills the lower right where wave activity exceeds 0.6. Three solid black contours mark mean compressibility thresholds at 0.085, 0.1, and 0.15. A dashed contour shows where the 75th percentile reaches 0.15.
summary.the_finding: Compressive fluctuations concentrate in the region of high helium and low wave activity, precisely the ambiguous zone that the companion paper's classification could not resolve. The 0.15 compressibility contour closely follows the boundary of this problematic region. Above the blue dashed line marking the continuously open source boundary, mean compressibility drops sharply below 0.085 regardless of helium level. This confirms that helium-rich, wave-poor wind is characterized by compressive fluctuations.
summary.why_it_matters: This panel closes the loop between the companion paper's classification and this paper's compressibility analysis. The mysterious upper-left region with high helium and low wave activity is now identified as compressive wind. This resolves the companion paper's hypothesis about transients by providing the physical mechanism: compressive density fluctuations enhance helium independently of wave-driven processes in open-source wind.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_17a.summary_short: Compressive fluctuations concentrate in the region of high helium and low wave activity, precisely the ambiguous zone that the companion paper's classification could not resolve.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_17a.technical_caption: Panel (a): Mean |δnH/nH| as a function of |σc| and AHe. Solid black contours indicate |δnH/nH| = 0.085, 0.1, and 0.15. The dashed–dotted black contour indicates where the 75% quantile of |δnH/nH| = 0.15.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_17b.short_title: 75th percentile compressibility stays below 0.1 in open-source wind
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_17b.alt: This panel maps the 75th percentile of hydrogen compressibility (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and helium abundance (vertical axis).

summary.what_we_see: This panel maps the 75th percentile of hydrogen compressibility (color) across wave activity (horizontal axis) and helium abundance (vertical axis). A dashed blue line marks the wave activity boundary for continuously open source regions defined in the companion paper. Solid contours mark where the 75th percentile reaches 0.1 and 0.15. To the right of the blue line, in the open-source region, even the 75th percentile of compressibility does not exceed 0.1 for most of the plane. Above the blue line and at high helium, the 75th percentile exceeds 0.15.
summary.the_finding: In the region identified as continuously open source wind, even the 75th percentile of compressibility remains below 0.1, confirming that open-source wind is overwhelmingly incompressible. Only at the highest helium values with low wave activity does the 75th percentile exceed the 0.15 compressible threshold. The majority of the parameter space does not exceed 0.15, meaning the compressive population is concentrated in a specific corner rather than spread across the plane.
summary.why_it_matters: By examining the 75th percentile rather than just the mean, this panel shows that the incompressible character of open-source wind is robust and not just an average effect. Even the upper tail of the compressibility distribution stays below 0.1 in the open-source region. This reinforces the identification of the high-helium, low-wave-activity corner as a distinct compressive population and supports the paper's inference that this population likely originates from neither traditional open nor closed magnetic source regions.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_17b.summary_short: In the region identified as continuously open source wind, even the 75th percentile of compressibility remains below 0.1, confirming that open-source wind is overwhelmingly incompressible.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_17b.technical_caption: Panel (b): 75% quantile |δnH/nH| as a function of |σc| and AHe. Solid contours indicate where the 75% quantile of |δnH/nH| = 0.1 and 0.15. The region of the plane with |σc| greater than that indicated by the dashed–dotted blue line corresponds to solar wind originating in continuously open source regions as defined in Paper I.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_18.short_title: Wave activity peaks near saturation helium for all compressibility levels
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_18.alt: Fifteen colored lines trace how wave activity (vertical axis) varies with helium abundance (horizontal axis), each representing a different compressibility level from low (dark blue) to high (pink).

summary.what_we_see: Fifteen colored lines trace how wave activity (vertical axis) varies with helium abundance (horizontal axis), each representing a different compressibility level from low (dark blue) to high (pink). Most curves rise from wave activity near 0.5 at low helium, reach a maximum near or just above the saturation abundance (green line), and then decline at higher helium. The most compressive curve (pink) remains nearly flat near 0.5 across helium abundances from 1 to 6 percent before decreasing. An orange-on-black line highlights the 0.085 compressibility level. Shaded regions indicate uncertainty.
summary.the_finding: Wave activity reaches a maximum near the saturation helium abundance for all but the most compressive quantile. Beyond saturation, behavior depends strongly on compressibility. Incompressible wind maintains high wave activity at above-saturation helium, consistent with steady Alfvenic fast wind. Compressive wind shows declining wave activity at above-saturation helium. The most compressive wind is nearly independent of helium at roughly 0.5 until helium exceeds about 6 percent. Below saturation, all incompressible curves collapse, showing that wave activity is independent of compressibility level for helium-poor wind.
summary.why_it_matters: By showing that wave activity behavior changes at the saturation point differently for compressible and incompressible wind, this figure reveals that the saturation point is a physical boundary where dominant solar wind processes change. The authors use this relationship to map compressibility quantiles to wave activity levels, enabling direct translation between the two analysis frameworks used in the companion paper and this one.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_18.summary_short: Wave activity reaches a maximum near the saturation helium abundance for all but the most compressive quantile.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_18.technical_caption: The average normalized cross helicity (|σc|) as a function of the helium abundance (AHe) in each of 15 compressibility (|δnH/nH|) quantiles. Shaded regions indicate the SEM. The color of each |δnH/nH| quantile is given by the color bar. Lines are smoothed with a 1σ Gaussian filter for visual clarity. Compressibilities |δnH/nH| > 0.15 are plotted in pink. The quantile corresponding to |δnH/nH| = 0.085 is highlighted by plotting the dotted orange line on top of a black solid line. The green line plots As(|σc|) in each |δnH/nH| quantile.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_19.short_title: Incompressible wind shows tightly bundled wave-activity curves
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_19.alt: Fifteen colored lines trace how wave activity (vertical axis) varies with solar wind speed (horizontal axis) at different compressibility levels.

summary.what_we_see: Fifteen colored lines trace how wave activity (vertical axis) varies with solar wind speed (horizontal axis) at different compressibility levels. For incompressible wind (cool-colored lines), wave activity rises steadily with speed and the curves cluster tightly together in a narrow bundle. For compressive wind (pink lines), wave activity is lower at all speeds and the curves separate from the incompressible bundle. A green line connects saturation speeds. An inset zooms into the saturation speed region. Above about 750 km/s, even incompressible curves show declining wave activity.
summary.the_finding: In incompressible wind, wave activity increases uniformly with speed regardless of the specific compressibility level, forming a tightly bundled set of curves. Speed is a reliable predictor of wave activity for incompressible wind. In compressive wind, wave activity is suppressed at all speeds and the curves separate clearly from the bundle. The saturation speed shifts to higher values for more compressive wind. This provides the mapping function used to translate compressibility quantiles into wave activity levels.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure provides the foundation for mapping between compressibility and wave activity frameworks. Because incompressible curves bundle tightly, the characteristic wave activity at any speed can be read off for any compressibility level below 0.15. The authors use this mapping to translate the companion paper's wave-activity results into this paper's compressibility framework, enabling the direct cross-validation that follows in subsequent figures.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_19.summary_short: In incompressible wind, wave activity increases uniformly with speed regardless of the specific compressibility level, forming a tightly bundled set of curves.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_20.short_title: Low-wave wind becomes most compressible at high speeds
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_20.alt: Fifteen colored lines trace how compressibility (vertical axis) varies with solar wind speed (horizontal axis), each representing a different wave activity level from low (dark purple) to high (dark red).

summary.what_we_see: Fifteen colored lines trace how compressibility (vertical axis) varies with solar wind speed (horizontal axis), each representing a different wave activity level from low (dark purple) to high (dark red). At slow speeds, all curves converge below 0.1. As speed increases, the curves fan apart: low-wave-activity wind (cool colors) becomes increasingly compressible, while high-wave-activity wind (warm colors) becomes less compressible. A green line connects saturation speeds. At the highest speeds above about 750 km/s, even Alfvenic wind shows a spike in compressibility.
summary.the_finding: Compressibility is nearly independent of wave activity in slow wind, converging below 0.1, but diverges dramatically in fast wind. The lowest-wave-activity wind becomes the most compressible at high speeds, while the highest-wave-activity wind becomes the least compressible. This fan-like divergence begins near the saturation speed and grows wider with increasing speed. At the fastest observed speeds above about 750 km/s, compressibility increases markedly even in Alfvenic wind, though the statistics at those speeds are limited.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure provides the inverse mapping: given a wave activity level, what is the corresponding compressibility at each speed? Together with Figure 19, it establishes a bidirectional translation between the companion paper's wave-activity framework and this paper's compressibility framework. This translation is essential because different instruments may measure one quantity more easily than the other, and the authors show these measurements carry equivalent source region information.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_20.summary_short: Compressibility is nearly independent of wave activity in slow wind, converging below 0.1, but diverges dramatically in fast wind.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_20.technical_caption: The hydrogen compressibility |δnH/nH| as a function of the solar wind speed vsw in quantiles of |σc|, which is given by the color bar. The green line labeled vs indicates |δnH/nH| in each |σc| quantile at the corresponding saturation abundance.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_21.short_title: Compressibility reaches a minimum above saturation helium
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_21.alt: Fifteen colored lines trace how compressibility (vertical axis) varies with helium abundance (horizontal axis), each for a different wave activity level from low (purple) to high (red).

summary.what_we_see: Fifteen colored lines trace how compressibility (vertical axis) varies with helium abundance (horizontal axis), each for a different wave activity level from low (purple) to high (red). Alfvenic curves show compressibility decreasing as helium increases from low values, while non-Alfvenic curves remain approximately constant for helium below about 5 percent. All curves converge to a minimum compressibility of 0.067 at helium around 5.3 percent. Beyond this minimum, behavior diverges: low-wave-activity wind shows compressibility rising again, while high-wave-activity wind maintains low compressibility. A green line marks the saturation abundance. An inset zooms into the saturation region.
summary.the_finding: Compressibility reaches a minimum of 0.067 at helium abundance around 5.3 percent, which is distinctly above the saturation abundance of 3.8 to 4.2 percent. Below this minimum, Alfvenic curves show decreasing compressibility with increasing helium, while non-Alfvenic curves remain approximately constant. Above the minimum, low-wave-activity wind becomes more compressible while high-wave-activity wind stays incompressible. This minimum establishes an additional physical scale in the helium-compressibility relationship.
summary.why_it_matters: The compressibility minimum at helium around 5.3 percent, above the saturation abundance, provides a physical scale derived from a completely different measurement than helium or speed. This feature strengthens confidence that the relationship between compressibility and helium abundance reflects genuine transitions in solar wind physics, likely tied to the magnetic topology of source regions on the Sun and the processes governing helium fractionation in the corona.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_21.summary_short: Compressibility reaches a minimum of 0.067 at helium abundance around 5.3 percent, which is distinctly above the saturation abundance of 3.8 to 4.2 percent.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_22.short_title: Mapped compressibility quantiles recover the wave-activity pattern
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_22.alt: Two panels show saturation speed (panel a) and saturation abundance (panel b) plotted against wave activity, after mapping each compressibility level to its corresponding wave activity value.

summary.what_we_see: Two panels show saturation speed (panel a) and saturation abundance (panel b) plotted against wave activity, after mapping each compressibility level to its corresponding wave activity value. Panel (a) uses the speed mapping from Figure 19; panel (b) uses the helium mapping from Figure 18. Points are colored by compressibility and connected by dotted lines with gray error envelopes. Cyan horizontal bands mark the Low, Mid, and High wave-activity intervals from the companion paper. The filled marker at 0.085 compressibility separates regimes. Incompressible points cluster at wave activity near 0.6, while compressible points map to lower wave activity.
summary.the_finding: When compressibility-derived saturation points are mapped to wave activity, they recover the same three-interval pattern found in the companion paper's direct analysis. Low, Mid, and High wave-activity intervals correspond to high, intermediate, and low compressibility respectively. The mapping is monotonic and well-behaved for incompressible wind, confirming that compressibility and wave activity carry equivalent information. The 0.085 compressibility level maps to roughly the 0.6 to 0.65 wave activity boundary.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure validates the paper's central methodological claim: results from compressibility analysis can be faithfully translated into the wave-activity framework and vice versa. The successful mapping demonstrates that hydrogen compressibility and normalized cross helicity are complementary measures of the same underlying physics, providing two independent windows into source region identification.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_22.summary_short: When compressibility-derived saturation points are mapped to wave activity, they recover the same three-interval pattern found in the companion paper's direct analysis.

Uncertainties are plotted as error bars with the same color as the markers, and a semitransparent gray envelope traces out the envelope surrounding the error bars. Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_23.short_title: Bimodal slope split persists after mapping to wave activity
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_23.alt: Two panels show the saturation slope (helium gradient above saturation, vertical axis) mapped to wave activity (horizontal axis).

summary.what_we_see: Two panels show the saturation slope (helium gradient above saturation, vertical axis) mapped to wave activity (horizontal axis). Panel (a) maps via saturation speed and panel (b) via saturation abundance. Incompressible points (open circles) cluster at near-zero slopes at moderate-to-high wave activity around 0.6. Compressive points (pink squares) map to low wave activity below 0.55 with dramatically larger slopes. A clear gap separates the two groups in both panels. The filled marker at 0.085 compressibility sits at the boundary.
summary.the_finding: The bimodal split between compressive and incompressible saturation slopes survives mapping to wave activity. Incompressible points all map to wave activity above roughly 0.6 with near-zero slopes, while compressive points map below 0.55 with slopes five to six times larger. The gap between groups is wide and clean in both panels, meaning these are truly distinct populations rather than arbitrary divisions of a continuous distribution.
summary.why_it_matters: The persistence of the bimodal split after mapping confirms that compressive and incompressible populations are physically distinct solar wind types. The large gap suggests that compressive helium enhancement is a threshold phenomenon: either significant compressive fluctuations drive helium above saturation, or they do not. There is no gradual transition, reinforcing the practical utility of the 0.15 compressibility threshold for source region classification.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_23.summary_short: The bimodal split between compressive and incompressible saturation slopes survives mapping to wave activity.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_23.technical_caption: The saturation slopes from Figure 12 as a function of |σc|. Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_24.short_title: All wave-activity quantiles map to incompressible compressibility
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_24.alt: Two panels show saturation speed (panel a) and saturation abundance (panel b) from the companion paper's wave-activity analysis, mapped to their corresponding compressibility values (horizontal axis).

summary.what_we_see: Two panels show saturation speed (panel a) and saturation abundance (panel b) from the companion paper's wave-activity analysis, mapped to their corresponding compressibility values (horizontal axis). Points are colored by wave activity and connected by dotted lines with gray error envelopes. Blue bands mark the Low, Mid, and High wave-activity intervals. All mapped points cluster in a narrow compressibility range from 0.07 to 0.14, well below the 0.15 threshold. Higher wave activity maps to lower compressibility monotonically.
summary.the_finding: Every saturation point from the companion paper's wave-activity analysis maps to the incompressible regime. Neither the saturation speed nor the saturation abundance maps to a compressibility above 0.15. The Mid and High wave-activity subsets cluster tightly below 0.085, while the Low wave-activity subset extends to higher compressibility near 0.14. The roughly linear decrease of saturation abundance with increasing mapped compressibility in panel (b) extrapolates to 4.76 percent helium at zero compressibility.
summary.why_it_matters: This inverse mapping completes the bidirectional validation between the two papers. By showing that the companion paper's results all fall in the incompressible regime, the authors demonstrate that the dominant compressibility depends on how observations are aggregated across wave-activity quantiles. Compressive wind, while significant in driving anomalous helium gradients, does not dominate any single wave-activity quantile. This underscores why conditioning on compressibility before analyzing helium-speed trends yields cleaner results.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_24.summary_short: Every saturation point from the companion paper's wave-activity analysis maps to the incompressible regime.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_25.short_title: Less wave-active wind carries up to 40% excess helium at 800 km/s
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_25.alt: This scatter plot shows how much extra helium the solar wind carries at 800 km/s beyond the saturation level (vertical axis, as a ratio to saturation abundance), plotted against wave activity (horizontal axis).

summary.what_we_see: This scatter plot shows how much extra helium the solar wind carries at 800 km/s beyond the saturation level (vertical axis, as a ratio to saturation abundance), plotted against wave activity (horizontal axis). Points run from dark blue (lowest wave activity) at upper left to dark red (highest wave activity) at lower right. A dashed fit line traces a clear linear downward trend. The most wave-active wind has about 10 percent excess helium, while the least wave-active wind has about 40 percent excess.
summary.the_finding: Helium enhancement above saturation at 800 km/s decreases linearly with increasing wave activity. The least wave-active wind carries roughly 40 percent more helium than the saturation value, while the most wave-active wind carries about 10 percent more. The linear fit extrapolates to 46 percent excess in perfectly non-Alfvenic wind. Even the most Alfvenic wind carries about 10 percent excess, seemingly contradicting the expectation that fast-wind helium should not exceed about 50 percent of the photospheric value.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure motivates the paper's central analysis. The apparent contradiction between the observed 10 to 40 percent helium excess and the expected upper bound from coronal fractionation is what drives the need for the compressibility framework. The paper resolves this by showing that compressive fluctuations inflate the helium measurement, meaning the excess does not require revising the photospheric upper bound. Instead, it reflects the mixing of compressive events into the fast-wind population.

Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_25.summary_short: Helium enhancement above saturation at 800 km/s decreases linearly with increasing wave activity.
Alterman_2026_ApJL_996_L12/fig_25.technical_caption: Helium abundance at 800 km/s derived from the fits of AHe(vsw) across |σc| quantiles in Paper I, each scaled to the saturation abundance As in that paper. aa51550-24/fig_1.short_title: Helium abundance saturates at 402 km/s in the solar wind
aa51550-24/fig_1.alt: A filled contour plot shows how helium concentration in the solar wind varies with solar wind speed, measured by the Wind spacecraft.

summary.what_we_see: A filled contour plot shows how helium concentration in the solar wind varies with solar wind speed, measured by the Wind spacecraft. The horizontal axis spans speeds from 300 to 700 km/s; the vertical axis shows helium abundance on a logarithmic scale. Warm yellows and oranges mark where measurements cluster most densely at each speed, while dark purples and blacks indicate rare measurements. A green line with error bars traces the average helium abundance at each speed. A magenta dash-dotted line shows a two-segment (bilinear) fit, and light blue crosshairs mark where the two segments meet, near 400 km/s.
summary.the_finding: Helium abundance rises steeply with solar wind speed up to about 402 km/s, then levels off at roughly half its photospheric value. The bilinear fit precisely locates this saturation point, quantifying what earlier studies described only qualitatively. Below this speed, helium concentration increases steadily; above it, helium holds approximately constant. This saturation speed has long been taken as the dividing line between slow and fast solar wind.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure establishes the baseline that the rest of the paper challenges. The helium-based 400 km/s transition has shaped how scientists classify solar wind and trace it back to source regions on the Sun for decades. By rigorously quantifying this transition speed and abundance, the authors set the stage for comparing helium against heavier elements and ultimately showing that the traditional boundary may be misleading.

aa51550-24/fig_1.summary_short: Helium abundance rises steeply with solar wind speed up to about 402 km/s, then levels off at roughly half its photospheric value.
aa51550-24/fig_1.technical_caption: Contour plot corresponding to a column-normalized 2D histogram of the SWE helium abundance as a function of the proton speed observed at Wind. The solid green line and error bars are the mean and standard deviation in each column. The dash-dotted pink line shows the result of a bilinear fit to the green line, where each line is selected as the minimum of both lines in the bilinear function over the full domain. Only speeds of vsw > 300 km s⁻¹ are included in the fit. Semitransparent blue lines indicate the saturation speed (vs) and saturation abundance (As) along with their uncertainties, where the bilinear function changes slope.

aa51550-24/fig_2.short_title: Heavy ions transition to fast wind 75 km/s slower than helium
aa51550-24/fig_2.alt: Ten colored curves track the photospheric-normalized abundance of different chemical elements against solar wind speed, spanning roughly 300 to 650 km/s.

summary.what_we_see: Ten colored curves track the photospheric-normalized abundance of different chemical elements against solar wind speed, spanning roughly 300 to 650 km/s. Each species has a unique color and marker shape: silicon (purple pentagons) and iron (pink stars) reach the highest values while neon (red diamonds) and helium (blue circles) sit lowest. Semitransparent vertical lines in each species' color mark the speed where its bilinear fit changes slope. For elements heavier than helium these lines cluster near 327 km/s, while the helium lines sit to the right near 390 to 402 km/s. Species labels appear at the right edge.
summary.the_finding: Every element follows the same two-regime pattern: a steep rise at lower speeds and a shallower trend at higher speeds. The speed at which this transition occurs differs between helium and heavier elements. All elements heavier than helium transition near 327 km/s on average, about 63 km/s slower than helium's 390 km/s as measured by the same instrument. This gap shows that helium and heavier elements respond differently to whatever process separates fast from slow solar wind.
summary.why_it_matters: This is the paper's central result. If scientists use helium or the traditional 400 to 600 km/s range to separate fast from slow wind, they inadvertently mix solar wind from polar coronal holes with wind from equatorial sources that have intermittently open magnetic fields. Heavier elements place the true boundary lower, with direct consequences for correctly tracing the solar wind back to its origin on the Sun and understanding how different source regions contribute.

aa51550-24/fig_2.summary_short: Every element follows the same two-regime pattern: a steep rise at lower speeds and a shallower trend at higher speeds.
aa51550-24/fig_2.technical_caption: Abundances averaged in solar wind speed bins. Saturation speeds (vs) are indicated by vertical lines of the corresponding color. The species are indicated on the right hand side of the plot. The SWE observations of AHe from Figure 1 are shown for reference in pink hexagons and labeled SWE. Only every second bin is marked for visual clarity.

aa51550-24/fig_3.short_title: Slow wind composition is universal; fast wind fractionates by mass
aa51550-24/fig_3.alt: The same ten element curves from Figure 2, now rescaled so that each element's transition point sits at the coordinate (1, 1).

summary.what_we_see: The same ten element curves from Figure 2, now rescaled so that each element's transition point sits at the coordinate (1, 1). The horizontal axis shows speed divided by saturation speed (0.6 to 2.0); the vertical axis shows abundance divided by saturation abundance (0 to 2.2). Below the (1, 1) point, all ten curves collapse onto one rising line, overlapping tightly. Above it, the curves fan apart: nitrogen (orange X markers) and carbon (blue squares) climb highest to about 2.0, oxygen (green pluses) reaches roughly 1.8, neon through sulfur form an intermediate cluster near 1.3 to 1.5, and iron (pink stars) and helium barely rise above 1.0 to 1.15.
summary.the_finding: Below the transition speed, every element behaves identically once known compositional offsets are removed, indicating no element-specific fractionation operates in slow wind. Above the transition speed, the curves separate in an order related to element mass: lighter elements like carbon and nitrogen continue rising steeply while heavier ones like iron barely increase. This mass-dependent fanning reveals a previously unrecognized fractionation process operating exclusively in fast solar wind.
summary.why_it_matters: The universal behavior below the transition speed strongly supports the view that slow wind from equatorial sources has a single, consistent composition signature regardless of element. The mass-dependent separation above the transition speed points to an unknown acceleration or fractionation mechanism that treats heavy ions differently depending on their mass. Identifying this process could reveal new physics about how energy is deposited into the fast solar wind during its journey from the Sun.

aa51550-24/fig_3.summary_short: Below the transition speed, every element behaves identically once known compositional offsets are removed, indicating no element-specific fractionation operates in slow wind.
aa51550-24/fig_3.technical_caption: Observations plotted in Figure 2, but scaled to their (vs, As) values, which is plotted at (1, 1).

aa51550-24/fig_4.short_title: Transition speed does not depend on ionization energy
aa51550-24/fig_4.alt: A scatter plot shows each element's transition speed plotted against its first ionization potential, the energy needed to strip its outermost electron.

summary.what_we_see: A scatter plot shows each element's transition speed plotted against its first ionization potential, the energy needed to strip its outermost electron. The horizontal axis spans 6 to 30 electron volts; the vertical axis spans 320 to 400 km/s. A vertical black dashed line at 11 eV separates low-FIP elements on the left from high-FIP elements on the right. A broad horizontal cyan band at 327 km/s marks the weighted average transition speed for heavy elements. Most data points cluster within this band. Helium stands apart at the far right, with its SWICS measurement (blue circle) near 390 km/s and its SWE measurement (pink hexagon) near 402 km/s. Element names appear along the top axis in matching colors.
summary.the_finding: The fast-slow transition speed is essentially the same for all heavy elements regardless of how easily they are ionized. This independence from ionization energy means the transition is not driven by the chromospheric FIP effect, the well-known process that fractionates elements based on their first ionization potential. The responsible process must operate higher in the solar atmosphere, above where ionization-dependent fractionation occurs. Helium remains the clear outlier, transitioning at a markedly higher speed.
summary.why_it_matters: By ruling out the FIP effect as the driver of the fast-slow transition, this figure narrows down where in the Sun's atmosphere the boundary between wind types is established. The responsible mechanism must operate above the chromosphere, where all elements are already fully ionized. This constraint helps solar physicists focus their models on the correct altitude range and physical processes when seeking to understand what separates fast and slow solar wind.

aa51550-24/fig_4.summary_short: The fast-slow transition speed is essentially the same for all heavy elements regardless of how easily they are ionized.
aa51550-24/fig_4.technical_caption: Saturation speed (vs) as a function of the first ionization potential (FIP). The vertical dashed line is 11 eV, the nominal change between high and low FIP. The horizontal, semitransparent blue bar indicates the weighted average of vs = 327 ± 2 km s⁻¹ for elements heavier than He. To within their mutual uncertainties, all but Ne and Si have the same vs.

aa51550-24/fig_5.short_title: Transition abundances confirm expected FIP fractionation pattern
aa51550-24/fig_5.alt: A scatter plot shows each element's abundance at the transition speed, plotted against its first ionization potential.

summary.what_we_see: A scatter plot shows each element's abundance at the transition speed, plotted against its first ionization potential. The horizontal axis spans 6 to 30 eV; the vertical axis spans 0 to 1.0. A vertical black dashed line at 11 eV divides low-FIP from high-FIP elements. Low-FIP elements on the left reach high abundances: iron (dark star) and silicon (purple pentagon) near 0.93, sulfur (brown hexagon) near 0.73, and magnesium (pink diamond) near 0.65. High-FIP elements on the right sit lower: nitrogen (orange X) near 0.40, carbon (blue square) near 0.38, oxygen (green plus) near 0.35, and neon (red diamond) near 0.27. Helium appears at the far right with SWICS near 0.50 and SWE near 0.53. A dotted black line connects the points.
summary.the_finding: The roughly two-fold enhancement of low-FIP elements over high-FIP elements at the fast-slow transition point matches the well-established FIP effect pattern. This confirms that the transition abundances reflect genuine solar composition signatures set in the chromosphere, not artifacts of the bilinear fitting method. Sulfur behaving like a low-FIP element is consistent with independent observations from suprathermal ion measurements.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure serves as a critical consistency check for the entire analysis. If the bilinear fitting produced spurious transition points, the resulting abundances would not reproduce the well-known FIP pattern. Finding the expected step in abundances across the FIP boundary validates the analytical framework and gives confidence that the transition speeds and abundances identified throughout the paper reflect real physical boundaries in the solar wind, not statistical artifacts.

aa51550-24/fig_5.summary_short: The roughly two-fold enhancement of low-FIP elements over high-FIP elements at the fast-slow transition point matches the well-established FIP effect pattern.
aa51550-24/fig_5.technical_caption: Each element's saturation abundance (As) as a function of FIP. The vertical dashed line is 11 eV, the nominal change between high and low FIP. The ~2× difference between low and high FIP abundances is expected.

aa51550-24/fig_6.short_title: Fast wind reveals an unexplained mass-dependent fractionation
aa51550-24/fig_6.alt: A scatter plot shows how much each element's abundance at the fastest observed speed (592 km/s) exceeds its transition-point abundance, plotted against element mass in atomic mass units.

summary.what_we_see: A scatter plot shows how much each element's abundance at the fastest observed speed (592 km/s) exceeds its transition-point abundance, plotted against element mass in atomic mass units. The horizontal axis spans 0 to 60 amu; the vertical axis spans 0.75 to 2.25. Helium and SWE sit at mass 4 near 1.15. Carbon (blue square, mass 12) and nitrogen (orange X, mass 14) cluster near 2.0. Oxygen (green plus, mass 16) reaches about 1.8. Neon (red diamond, mass 20) is near 1.5. Magnesium (pink diamond, mass 24) sits near 1.35. Silicon (purple pentagon, mass 28) and sulfur (brown hexagon, mass 32) are near 1.4. Iron (pink star, mass 56) barely exceeds 1.05. A dotted line connects the points, and colored vertical bars show error ranges, which are largest for silicon and iron.
summary.the_finding: In fast solar wind, lighter heavy elements are enhanced more above their transition values than heavier ones, forming a clear mass-dependent trend. This pattern cannot be explained by the FIP effect (which depends on ionization energy, not mass), by hydrogen dragging ions outward through Coulomb collisions (which would be stronger in slow wind), or by gravitational settling (which requires closed magnetic loops absent in fast-wind source regions). The responsible mechanism remains unidentified.
summary.why_it_matters: Discovering an unexplained mass-dependent process operating exclusively in fast solar wind opens a new puzzle in solar physics. The authors systematically rule out every known candidate mechanism, including ponderomotive-force-driven FIP fractionation, Coulomb friction, and gravitational settling. Identifying this process could reveal how energy is deposited into the fast solar wind and how that energy couples differently to ions of different masses.

aa51550-24/fig_6.summary_short: In fast solar wind, lighter heavy elements are enhanced more above their transition values than heavier ones, forming a clear mass-dependent trend.
aa51550-24/fig_6.technical_caption: Abundance at vsw = 592 km s⁻¹ normalized to As as a function of the element mass. Excluding He, the decreasing trend with increasing M indicates a heavy ion fractionation process in fast solar wind.

aa51550-24/fig_7.short_title: Heavy and helium transition speeds bracket the most common wind
aa51550-24/fig_7.alt: A stepped blue histogram on a logarithmic vertical scale shows the probability density of solar wind speed observations, spanning roughly 200 to 800 km/s.

summary.what_we_see: A stepped blue histogram on a logarithmic vertical scale shows the probability density of solar wind speed observations, spanning roughly 200 to 800 km/s. The distribution peaks sharply near 345 km/s and drops off on both sides, with a long tail toward higher speeds. Two pairs of semitransparent green vertical lines mark the transition speeds and their uncertainties: one labeled 'Heavy vs' near 327 km/s on the rising side of the peak, and another labeled 'He vs' near 390 km/s on the falling side. A dotted black vertical line at 345 km/s marks the peak, sitting squarely between the two transition speeds.
summary.the_finding: The heavy-element transition speed sits just below the most commonly observed solar wind speed, while helium's transition speed sits above it. The two boundaries bracket the peak of the speed distribution, meaning the most frequently measured solar wind falls between them. Any single speed threshold chosen between 327 and 402 km/s classifies a substantial fraction of observations differently depending on whether helium or heavier elements serves as the guide.
summary.why_it_matters: This demonstrates that the mismatch between helium and heavy-element transitions has practical consequences for a large fraction of solar wind observations. Scientists trying to trace the solar wind back to its source on the Sun will misclassify the origin of the most commonly observed wind speeds if they use the wrong transition speed. The figure makes the stakes of the paper's findings immediately visible and concrete.

aa51550-24/fig_7.summary_short: The heavy-element transition speed sits just below the most commonly observed solar wind speed, while helium's transition speed sits above it.
aa51550-24/fig_7.technical_caption: Probability density of vsw observed by SWICS and SWE. The vertical green lines are saturation speeds vs including uncertainty. The vertical dotted black line is the peak solar wind speed bin, vsw = 345 km s⁻¹.

aa51550-24/fig_8.short_title: Charge state organizes fast wind fractionation into a tight trend
aa51550-24/fig_8.alt: A scatter plot shows the same fast-wind abundance ratios as Figure 6, but now plotted against each element's typical electrical charge in the solar wind rather than its mass.

summary.what_we_see: A scatter plot shows the same fast-wind abundance ratios as Figure 6, but now plotted against each element's typical electrical charge in the solar wind rather than its mass. The horizontal axis spans 0 to 12 elementary charges; the vertical axis spans 0.75 to 2.25. Helium sits at charge +2 near 1.15. Carbon (blue square) and nitrogen (orange X) at charges +5 to +6 cluster near 2.0. Oxygen (green plus) at charge +6 reaches about 1.8. Moving to higher charges, neon and silicon near +8, sulfur near +9, and magnesium near +9 form a descending sequence from about 1.5 to 1.35. Iron at charge +10 sits near 1.05. A dotted black line connects the points, revealing a smooth, nearly linear decline from low to high charge state.
summary.the_finding: The fast-wind fractionation correlates far more tightly with charge state than with mass, FIP, or mass-to-charge ratio, as measured by a robust coefficient of determination (R-squared of 0.95 for charge state versus below 0.55 for all other quantities tested). While mass orders the elements into three loose groups, charge state produces a smooth, nearly linear trend. This unexpected result suggests the unknown fractionation mechanism may couple to an element's electrical charge rather than its weight.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure provides the strongest observational clue about what drives the mysterious fast-wind fractionation. A charge-state dependence is unexpected, and the authors note they do not yet have a physical explanation for it. The tight correlation significantly narrows the space of possible physical mechanisms and will guide future theoretical work on understanding how the solar wind's composition is modified during its acceleration from the Sun to Earth.

aa54299-25/fig_1.short_title: Slow-wind helium swings with the sunspot cycle
aa54299-25/fig_1.alt: A time series spanning 1994–2022 plots the fraction of helium in the solar wind relative to the Sun's surface value.

summary.what_we_see: A time series spanning 1994–2022 plots the fraction of helium in the solar wind relative to the Sun's surface value. Each point averages roughly 250 days of Wind/SWE measurements. Light blue open hexagons trace helium in slower wind; orange filled hexagons show faster wind. A dashed black curve on the right axis marks the normalized sunspot number, cycling approximately every 11 years. Fast-wind helium hovers near a dotted horizontal line at about half the photospheric value, enclosed in a gray uncertainty band. Slow-wind helium swings dramatically in step with the sunspot curve. A cyan bar at the bottom marks when SWICS data are also available.
summary.the_finding: Slow-wind helium closely tracks the solar cycle, with a correlation coefficient of 0.94 against sunspot number. It drops to as low as 15% of its photospheric value during solar quiet periods and climbs to nearly 50% during solar maxima. Fast-wind helium also correlates with activity (r = 0.66) but oscillates in a much narrower range around 51 ± 3% of the photospheric value. This 51% ceiling appears to be a physical limit on how much helium the Sun launches into its steadiest outflows. Using a normalized sunspot number that accounts for varying cycle amplitudes tightens all correlations, indicating that the sunspot count is a clock for solar activity rather than a direct driver of helium variations.
summary.why_it_matters: By extending this analysis to wind speeds up to 800 km/s—nearly the full range of non-transient solar wind—the figure provides the most complete picture to date of how helium abundance evolves with the magnetic cycle. The 51% photospheric limit on fast-wind helium points to a process in or below the chromosphere and transition region that caps how much helium enters the solar wind. The distinction between fast and slow wind behavior supports the interpretation that these two wind populations originate from fundamentally different magnetic source regions, with the slow wind dominated by intermittently open structures whose properties change as the Sun's magnetic field reconfigures each cycle.

aa54299-25/fig_1.summary_short: Slow-wind helium closely tracks the solar cycle, with a correlation coefficient of 0.94 against sunspot number.
aa54299-25/fig_1.technical_caption: SWE helium abundance in fast (filled marker) and slow (empty marker) wind intervals as a function of time, aggregated down to 250 days. The right axis plots the normalized 13-month smoothed sunspot number. aa54299-25/fig_2.short_title: Slow-wind heavy element abundances dip at solar minimum
aa54299-25/fig_2.alt: Two panels spanning 1998–2012 track nine element abundances (He through Fe) relative to their photospheric values on a logarithmic vertical scale.

summary.what_we_see: Two panels spanning 1998–2012 track nine element abundances (He through Fe) relative to their photospheric values on a logarithmic vertical scale. Panel (a) shows fast wind; panel (b) shows slow wind. Each colored line and symbol represents a different element, with low ionization-potential species like iron (pink stars) and magnesium (pink diamonds) sitting highest and high ionization-potential species like helium (blue circles) and oxygen (green crosses) sitting lowest. A dashed black curve traces the normalized sunspot number on the right axis. Vertical lines mark solar minimum 24 (dotted brown) and the helium shutoff (dash-dotted black). Pink pentagon markers plot SWE helium for cross-validation with SWICS.
summary.the_finding: In the slow wind, all heavy element abundances except carbon track the solar cycle strongly, dropping during the deep solar minimum around 2008–2009 and recovering as activity rises. The depletion is visible across the full range of measured species, from nitrogen to iron. In the fast wind, abundances remain comparatively stable, consistent with origination from steadily open magnetic regions whose properties do not change dramatically with the cycle. The timing of the abundance minimum appears closer to the helium shutoff event than to the official sunspot minimum, suggesting these depletions share a common physical origin in the Sun's lower atmosphere.
summary.why_it_matters: This is the first systematic characterization of how nine heavy element abundances evolve with the solar cycle when separated by source region type using each element's saturation speed. The contrast between fast and slow wind confirms that the two populations originate from fundamentally different magnetic environments—continuously open versus intermittently open field lines. The low-FIP/high-FIP stratification visible across both panels reflects fractionation processes in the chromosphere and transition region. The near-coincidence of abundance minima with the helium shutoff suggests that a process deep in the solar atmosphere drives the depletion of all species simultaneously.

aa54299-25/fig_2.summary_short: In the slow wind, all heavy element abundances except carbon track the solar cycle strongly, dropping during the deep solar minimum around 2008–2009 and recovering as activity rises.
aa54299-25/fig_2.technical_caption: SWICS abundances normalized to their photospheric values in (a) fast and (b) slow wind as a function of time, aggregated in 250-day intervals. The right axes plots the normalized 13-month smoothed sunspot number. The SWE abundances normalized to its photospheric values are plotted for reference. The vertical dotted lines indicate solar minimum 24. The vertical dash-dotted line indicates the helium shutoff (Alterman et al. 2021).

aa54299-25/fig_3.short_title: Correlation with solar activity grows with element mass
aa54299-25/fig_3.alt: Each element's slow-wind correlation coefficient with solar activity is plotted against its atomic mass, from helium (~4 amu) on the left to iron (~56 amu) on the right.

summary.what_we_see: Each element's slow-wind correlation coefficient with solar activity is plotted against its atomic mass, from helium (~4 amu) on the left to iron (~56 amu) on the right. Open markers connected by a dash-dotted line show correlations computed with the standard sunspot number (SSN); filled markers connected by a solid line use the normalized sunspot number (NSSN). Element labels in matching colors run along the top axis, with vertical dotted lines linking each label to its data point. A separate marker near helium's mass labeled 'SWE' shows the Wind Faraday cup measurement, sitting above the SWICS helium point. From carbon through iron, correlation coefficients climb steadily upward.
summary.the_finding: For elements heavier than helium, the correlation between slow-wind abundance and solar activity rises monotonically with atomic mass—from carbon (~0.51–0.56) to iron (~0.82–0.84). This mass-dependent trend is a signature of gravitational settling: heavier elements sink faster in closed magnetic loops, so their abundances are more sensitive to how long those loops persist. Helium breaks this pattern, sitting well above the trend with a correlation as strong as iron's despite being the lightest element measured. This anomaly signals an additional process—helium's dynamic role in solar wind acceleration—that does not couple to heavier species.
summary.why_it_matters: This figure provides the clearest observational evidence that gravitational settling shapes the composition of slow solar wind from intermittently open source regions. The monotonic mass trend distinguishes gravitational settling from other fractionation processes like the FIP effect, which would produce a different ordering. Helium's departure from the trend constrains models of solar wind acceleration by requiring a mechanism that preferentially involves helium but not heavier ions. The consistently stronger correlations using the normalized sunspot number confirm that the sunspot count is a timing indicator for the solar cycle, not a direct physical driver of composition changes.

s11207-021-01801-9/fig_1.short_title: Helium depletes sharply before each solar cycle begins
s11207-021-01801-9/fig_1.alt: Panel A spans 1974 to 2020 and shows ten colored lines with distinct markers, each tracking helium percentage in the solar wind at a different wind speed (330 to 568 km/s, labeled in the top legend).

summary.what_we_see: Panel A spans 1974 to 2020 and shows ten colored lines with distinct markers, each tracking helium percentage in the solar wind at a different wind speed (330 to 568 km/s, labeled in the top legend). The lines rise and fall together over roughly 11-year intervals. A dashed black curve on the right axis traces the 13-month smoothed sunspot number. Vertical purple dash-dotted lines mark the official start of each solar cycle (minima 21 through 25); vertical magenta dotted lines with cyan uncertainty bands mark moments when helium suddenly dips. These dips consistently appear to the left of the purple lines, indicating they occur earlier. Panel B shows Lyman-alpha irradiance (solid blue) and F10.7 radio emission (dashed orange) over the same period, both lagging the sunspot minima.
summary.the_finding: Just before each new solar cycle begins, helium in the solar wind undergoes a rapid depletion and recovery that occurs at approximately the same time across all wind speeds. This helium shutoff consistently precedes the official sunspot-defined solar minimum by roughly 10 months, making it an earlier herald of the new cycle than sunspot counting or other standard activity indicators like Lyman-alpha and F10.7. The pattern repeats across all five solar minima observed in this 45-year dataset.
summary.why_it_matters: Predicting when a new solar cycle begins matters for forecasting space weather that affects satellites, power grids, and astronauts. The discovery that helium provides advance warning of solar cycle transitions offers a new forecasting tool. Because the shutoff occurs simultaneously across wind speeds, it likely reflects a fundamental change deep in the Sun rather than differences in how the solar wind is accelerated at the surface, pointing to a universal mechanism tied to the Sun's internal magnetic cycle.

s11207-021-01801-9/fig_2.short_title: Helium shutoff precedes each solar minimum by months
s11207-021-01801-9/fig_2.alt: The left panel shows five orange circles (one per solar cycle, 21 through 25) plotted against the y-axis labeled 'Time by which A_He Shutoff Heralds the Solar Cycle [Days],' ranging from 0 to 600 days.

summary.what_we_see: The left panel shows five orange circles (one per solar cycle, 21 through 25) plotted against the y-axis labeled 'Time by which A_He Shutoff Heralds the Solar Cycle [Days],' ranging from 0 to 600 days. Green dashed error bars show measurement precision; orange solid error bars show the combined uncertainty from precision and the averaging window. Cycles 21-24 cluster between about 180 and 310 days, while Cycle 25 stands out near 430 days. The right panel decomposes these uncertainties: orange squares show combined uncertainty, green diamonds show precision alone, and a red dash-dotted horizontal line at 125 days marks the window-size uncertainty. The green diamond for Cycle 22 peaks sharply, while Cycle 24's drops near zero.
summary.the_finding: Helium shutoff precedes the official start of a new solar cycle by roughly 200 to 430 days, with a precision-weighted average of about 229 days. For every cycle except Cycle 22, the 250-day averaging window is the dominant source of uncertainty, not the measurement precision. This means the shutoff timing could be pinpointed more sharply with finer time resolution. Cycle 25's shutoff occurred particularly early, about 430 days before the announced minimum, hinting that the official December 2019 minimum date may have occurred earlier than announced.
summary.why_it_matters: Quantifying exactly how far in advance helium signals a new solar cycle is essential for turning this discovery into a practical forecasting tool. That the averaging window rather than measurement noise limits timing precision suggests future analyses with higher time resolution could substantially sharpen the forecast. A reliable 6-to-12-month advance warning of solar cycle transitions would benefit satellite operators, power grid planners, and anyone who needs to prepare for changing space weather conditions.

s11207-021-01801-9/fig_3.short_title: Helium shutoff cycle length matches the sunspot cycle
s11207-021-01801-9/fig_3.alt: A single panel plots cycle length in years (y-axis, ranging from 9 to 13) against solar cycle number (x-axis, cycles 21 through 24).

summary.what_we_see: A single panel plots cycle length in years (y-axis, ranging from 9 to 13) against solar cycle number (x-axis, cycles 21 through 24). Blue plus signs connected by a blue line show sunspot-defined cycle lengths. Orange circles connected by an orange line show the time between consecutive helium shutoffs. Green error bars indicate precision-only uncertainty; orange error bars include the averaging window. Both traces follow the same up-and-down pattern: Cycle 22 is shortest at about 9.7 years, Cycle 23 is longest at about 12.5 to 13 years, and Cycles 21 and 24 fall in between near 10.3 to 10.5 years. The two curves nearly overlap at every point.
summary.the_finding: The time between successive helium shutoffs tracks the sunspot cycle length almost exactly. For Cycles 21 and 22, the two measures are identical; for Cycles 23 and 24, they agree to within one 250-day averaging window. This close match across four consecutive cycles confirms that helium shutoffs are not random fluctuations but are systematically tied to the same underlying solar clock that drives sunspot activity.
summary.why_it_matters: Demonstrating that helium shutoffs mark the same cycle as sunspot minima, just earlier, establishes helium as a legitimate independent solar cycle indicator. Having multiple independent markers of the same cycle helps scientists cross-validate their understanding of the Sun's magnetic activity, improves confidence in cycle timing, and opens the door to using in-situ solar wind measurements as a complement to traditional remote observations of the solar surface.

s11207-021-01801-9/fig_4.short_title: Shutoff timing holds steady across averaging window sizes
s11207-021-01801-9/fig_4.alt: The left panel plots the change in helium shutoff date (y-axis, ranging from -500 to +500 days) as a function of averaging window size (x-axis, 225 to 275 days).

summary.what_we_see: The left panel plots the change in helium shutoff date (y-axis, ranging from -500 to +500 days) as a function of averaging window size (x-axis, 225 to 275 days). Five color-coded traces with distinct markers represent the shutoff heralding each solar cycle (21 through 25), each with dashed error bars showing variability across wind speeds. Two horizontal cyan lines at +125 and -125 days mark the bounds of a single 250-day window. The right panel to the right of a vertical black divider shows a single weighted-average data point per cycle with standard-error-of-the-mean error bars. Most traces cluster within the cyan bands, except Cycle 22's orange trace, which drifts systematically toward negative values (earlier dates).
summary.the_finding: For four of five solar cycles, varying the averaging window size by up to 25 days shifts the identified shutoff date by less than one window length, confirming the result is robust. Cycle 22 is the sole exception, showing a systematic drift toward earlier dates with larger windows, which suggests its true shutoff may have occurred somewhat earlier than the baseline 250-day estimate. The weighted averages in the right panel confirm this stability for Cycles 21, 23, 24, and 25.
summary.why_it_matters: Sensitivity tests like this are essential for establishing that a newly discovered phenomenon is real rather than an artifact of data processing choices. Showing that helium shutoff timing barely changes with averaging window size builds confidence that the shutoffs reflect genuine solar physics. This robustness is a prerequisite for the community to adopt helium shutoff as a reliable, independent marker of solar cycle transitions for space weather forecasting.

s11207-021-01801-9/fig_5.short_title: Shutoff timing holds steady across window start dates

summary.what_we_see: The layout mirrors Figure 4. The left panel plots the change in helium shutoff date (y-axis, -500 to +500 days) as the window start time is pushed forward from 0 to 250 days (x-axis). Five color-coded traces with distinct markers represent the cycles heralded (21 through 25), each with dashed error bars. Horizontal cyan lines at +125 and -125 days mark the one-window-length boundary. The right panel shows weighted averages. Cycles 21, 23, 24, and 25 remain within or near the cyan bands. Cycle 22's orange trace again scatters broadly toward negative values, with its error bars extending well beyond the cyan bounds.
summary.the_finding: Sliding the averaging window start date forward by up to 250 days has little systematic effect on the identified shutoff timing for most cycles. Combined with the companion window-size test in Figure 4, this confirms that the helium shutoff is not sensitive to the specific choice of when averaging windows begin. Cycle 22 again stands out as the exception, showing a bias toward earlier dates. Together, these two figures demonstrate that neither parameter materially changes the result for four of five cycles.
summary.why_it_matters: This second sensitivity test completes the robustness argument begun in Figure 4. By showing that neither window size nor window start time systematically shifts the result, the authors establish helium shutoff as a reproducible, method-independent feature of the solar wind. Demonstrating insensitivity to analysis choices is a necessary step before the broader scientific community can adopt helium shutoff as a reliable solar cycle marker for space weather forecasting.

s11207-021-01801-9/fig_6.short_title: Helium shutoff coincides with new-cycle magnetic emergence
s11207-021-01801-9/fig_6.alt: The top panel repeats the helium time series from Figure 1 zoomed into 1995-2021, covering Cycles 23 and 24.

summary.what_we_see: The top panel repeats the helium time series from Figure 1 zoomed into 1995-2021, covering Cycles 23 and 24. Ten colored lines track helium abundance at different wind speeds; a dashed black curve shows sunspot number. Vertical cyan and magenta lines mark solar minima and helium shutoffs. The bottom panel shows a filled contour map of EUV brightpoint density versus solar latitude and time. Green, orange, and white contours sweep from mid-latitudes toward the equator over each cycle, forming the classic butterfly pattern. A dotted yellow-black line traces the 0.8 density threshold. Semitransparent blue lines mark latitudes of plus and minus 25 degrees. A gray band and colored bars indicate Parker Solar Probe encounters and Solar Orbiter's launch.
summary.the_finding: Helium shutoff occurs at approximately the same time that new-cycle brightpoints emerge at mid-latitudes, particularly in the hemisphere that leads the new cycle. For Cycle 24, brightpoints appeared first in the northern hemisphere; for Cycle 25, the southern hemisphere led. This temporal coincidence connects an in-situ solar wind measurement (helium composition near Earth) with a remote observation of the Sun's surface (EUV brightpoints), suggesting both respond to the same underlying event: the cancelation of the old cycle's magnetic flux at the equator and the emergence of the new cycle's toroidal magnetic bands.
summary.why_it_matters: This connection between solar wind composition and the Sun's magnetic butterfly pattern provides a physical explanation for why helium signals the new cycle early. It ties a quantity measured near Earth to fundamental processes in the Sun's magnetic dynamo, specifically the death of one extended cycle's equatorial flux bands and the rise of the next. As Parker Solar Probe and Solar Orbiter explore ever closer to the Sun, they can test this connection directly, potentially revealing how deep magnetic restructuring propagates outward to change the solar wind composition we detect at Earth.
